Job.JobDescription:
The Girls Basketball Junior Varsity Coach role at Normandy High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Girls Basketball Junior Varsity Coach is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Normandy High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Girls Basketball Junior Varsity Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Girls Basketball Junior Varsity Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Girls Basketball Junior Varsity Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Normandy High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Girls Basketball Junior Varsity Coach at Normandy High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
UA City Schools New Hire Coaching Application: Job posting for coaches already hired into the district.
Employee shall remain free of any alcohol or non-prescribed controlled substance, use in the workplace throughout his/her employment with the District.
The Upper Arlington City School District Board of Education does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, including sexual orientation and transgender identity, disability, age, religion, military status, ancestry genetic information, or any other legally protected category, in its program and activities, including employment opportunities.
This job description is subject to change and in no manner states or implies that these are the only duties and responsibilities to be performed by the incumbent. The incumbent will be required to follow the instructions and perform the duties required by the incumbent's supervisor and or appointing authority.

JOB SUMMARY This position is responsible for coaching and providing direction to student athletes so that they achieve a high level of skill as well as an appreciation for discipline, sportsmanship and teamwork in softball.
QUALIFICATIONS High School certification and previous interscholastic softball coaching experience preferred. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skill and/or ability required. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
Education and/or Experience: High school certification and three years head coaching experience preferred. Prior successful experience working in a school setting or coaching student athletes strongly preferred.
Accurate Reporting: Educators shall accurately report information required by the local board of education or governing board, state education agency, federal agency or state or federal law.
Financial Management: Educators shall ensure all school funds and accounts are managed in a responsible and transparent manner. Educators shall ensure school property, public funds or fees paid by students or the community are not used for personal gain. Educators shall not make decisions based upon gifts, gratuities, favors or the socioeconomic status of parents, family members, community members or businesses.
Interpersonal Skills: Works well with others from diverse backgrounds. Focuses on solving conflict; maintaining confidentiality; listening to others without interrupting; keeping emotions under control; remaining open to others’ ideas and contributing to building a positive team spirit. Demonstrated ability to successfully coach, lead and/or motivate adolescent students.
Culture and Team building: Ability to work in alignment with the district’s strategic plan. Conducts oneself in a manner consistent with the district’s core values, mission and vision. Demonstrates ability to build relationships with athletes, parents and school community. Demonstrated ability and experience in creating and maintaining a positive and inclusive team environment
Language Skills: Ability to communicate fluently verbally and in writing in English. Ability to effectively present information and respond effectively to questions in one-on-one, small group situations to students and other school staff. Ability to verbally respond to common inquiries from students. Ability to read and interpret documents such as safety rules, operating instructions, procedure manuals and regulations. Ability to write general reports and correspondence.
Mathematical Skills: Ability to add, subtract, multiply and divide in all units of measure, using whole numbers, common fractions and decimals. Ability to compute rate, ratio and percent.
Reasoning Ability: Ability to define problems, collect data, establish facts and draw valid conclusions. Demonstrated ability and experience in executing coaching decisions and player selection in a fair, equitable and consistent manner
Ability to interpret an extensive variety of instructions in varying forms. Ability to problem solve and deal with a variety of concrete variables in situations where only limited standardization exists.
Computer Skills: General knowledge of computer usage and ability to use, e-mail, internet software and word processing software. Ability to type accurately and proficiently.
Other Skills and Abilities: Demonstrated knowledge of child growth and development at each level of instruction and of the social, emotional, physical and cognitive development of adolescent students. Demonstrated ability to participate in physically demanding athletic activities. Possesses knowledge of effective behavior management methods. Ability to exercise good judgment and work in a dynamic environment.
Certificates, Licenses, Registrations: Must hold or be willing to obtain the following certifications: Fundamentals of Coaching, Concussion Training, First Aid or Sports Injury Prevention Training, CPR/AED, Sudden Cardiac Arrest (Lindsay’s Law), Ohio Department of Education Pupil Activity Permit.
ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES
Essential duties of this position include the following. Other duties may be assigned.
1. Follows and maintains knowledge of all District policies and procedures. 2. Instructs and teaches skill sets and techniques necessary for individual and team achievement in softball 3. Establishes a fair and objective manner for executing player selection and effectively communicates with students regarding selection decisions for team rosters 4. Demonstrates a willingness to meet with the parent(s) or guardian(s) of any student who is a member or trying out for the team 5. Demonstrates the ability and/or experience to create and maintain an inclusive team culture 6. Plans and sets-up activities, practices, and games in conjunction with the athletic director 7. Ensures a certified coach is present at all softball practices and games 8. Develops appropriate training programs and practice schedules 9. Ensures that proper cleaning, storage, and maintenance of all athletic equipment and uniforms and updated inventories are adhered to 10. Arranges game transportation for athletic participants in conjunction with department of student life 11. Travels with student athletes for all events or assigns a School District approved designee to travel with all other levels, on the team bus both to and from games 12. Adheres to all financial policies of the district in regard to the collection and disbursement of money, expenses, and receipts 13. Makes recommendations regarding the purchase of uniforms, equipment and supplies 14. Works directly with the Athletic Director in preparing softball practice and game schedules 15. Maintains necessary records and completes required paperwork in a specified time and manner 16. Ensures that proper form(s) (insurance, attendance, medical) are obtained and current 17. Ensures that all student athletes practicing or playing have been cleared through the Athletic Director’s office 18. Enforces discipline policies and emphasizes sportsmanship and healthy lifestyles. Supervises students in locker rooms at home and away games and ensures appropriate behavior 19. Checks and secures all office, storage room, outside doors, locker rooms and all lights after the last player leaves after games and practices (Head Coach may delegate this responsibility to an Assistant Coach) 20. Ensures that appropriate rules and regulations regarding the conduct and eligibility of athletic activities and athletes are explained and followed 21. Maintains a safe environment and facilities for student athletes at all times

The Assistant Fast Pitch Coach position at NORMAN NORTH HIGH SCHOOL is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Assistant Fast Pitch Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At NORMAN NORTH HIGH SCHOOL, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Assistant Fast Pitch Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Assistant Fast Pitch Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Assistant Fast Pitch Coach role at NORMAN NORTH HIGH SCHOOL is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: Head Boys Tennis Coach - Ida B. Wells HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Boys Tennis Coach - Ida B. Wells HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics at Ida B. Wells HS is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Head Boys Tennis Coach - Ida B. Wells HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Ida B. Wells HS reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Head Boys Tennis Coach - Ida B. Wells HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Head Boys Tennis Coach - Ida B. Wells HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Head Boys Tennis Coach - Ida B. Wells HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Ida B. Wells HS. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: Head Girls Soccer Coach - Franklin HS - 26/27 SY - District Athletics
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Girls Soccer Coach - Franklin HS - 26/27 SY - District Athletics role at Franklin HS emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Head Girls Soccer Coach - Franklin HS - 26/27 SY - District Athletics reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Franklin HS at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Head Girls Soccer Coach - Franklin HS - 26/27 SY - District Athletics may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. Athlete support is ongoing. The Head Girls Soccer Coach - Franklin HS - 26/27 SY - District Athletics monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Head Girls Soccer Coach - Franklin HS - 26/27 SY - District Athletics must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Franklin HS.

Job.JobTitle: Golf - Boys Head Coach, McKay High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Golf - Boys Head Coach, McKay High School position at McKay High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Golf - Boys Head Coach, McKay High School prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At McKay High School, the Golf - Boys Head Coach, McKay High School works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Golf - Boys Head Coach, McKay High School encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Golf - Boys Head Coach, McKay High School at McKay High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

The Head JVIII Volleyball Coach - E803SY2526 at Century High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Head JVIII Volleyball Coach - E803SY2526 is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Century High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Head JVIII Volleyball Coach - E803SY2526 helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Head JVIII Volleyball Coach - E803SY2526 works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Century High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Century High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Head JVIII Volleyball Coach - E803SY2526 reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Head JVIII Volleyball Coach - E803SY2526 role at Century High School.

Job.JobTitle: .5 FTE Assistant Wrestling Coach - La Pine Middle School - Regular
Job.JobDescription:
The .5 FTE Assistant Wrestling Coach - La Pine Middle School - Regular position at La Pine Middle School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the .5 FTE Assistant Wrestling Coach - La Pine Middle School - Regular works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The .5 FTE Assistant Wrestling Coach - La Pine Middle School - Regular at La Pine Middle School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At La Pine Middle School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The .5 FTE Assistant Wrestling Coach - La Pine Middle School - Regular encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The .5 FTE Assistant Wrestling Coach - La Pine Middle School - Regular is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the .5 FTE Assistant Wrestling Coach - La Pine Middle School - Regular position at La Pine Middle School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobTitle: 1.0 FTE Boy's Tennis Head Coach - Caldera High School - Regular
Job.JobDescription: Our goal is to find the best candidate for the position, and we acknowledge that that candidate may be an individual from a less traditional background. We encourage you to apply, even if you don't believe you meet every one of our qualifications described. If you are unsure whether you meet the qualifications of a position, or how this would be determined, please feel free to contact Human Resources to discuss your application. As you prepare to submit your application for employment, please note that all consideration of experience for the position and initial salary placements will be based upon the information you submit with your original application. Resumes must be detailed and verifiable for successful experience credit, any information provided to Bend-La Pine Schools at a later date will not be the basis for adjustments in salary placement. Bend La Pine Schools Head Coaching Details Applicant must submit: 1. Letter of application detailing experience. 2. Current Resume – listing experience related to this position and working with students. 3. A minimum of three letters of recommendation. 4. A minimum of three references with contact information. General Job Qualifications and Key Responsibilities of the Head Coach: Hold high ethical and professional standards. Be an appropriate role model for high school student-athletes. Hold high expectations and accountability academically and behaviorallyfor all student-athletes and coaching staff. Ability to develop, articulate, and implement a vision for program. Ability to work in a cooperative and harmonious manner in an educationally based, school-wide athletic program. Experience leading a comprehensive high school athletic program preferred. Be relationship/process oriented. Understand and provide information regarding eligibility, tryout process, cut process, and all other team-related information to include lettering, team rules, etc. Be creative and involved in all fundraising for the program. Communicate effectively with ALL stakeholders. Be an advocate for the multi-sport athlete.
Job.Location: Caldera High School, 60925 SE 15th Street, Bend, OR, 97702, United States

Job.JobTitle: .5 FTE Assistant Wrestling Coach - La Pine Middle School - Regular
Job.JobDescription:
The .5 FTE Assistant Wrestling Coach - La Pine Middle School - Regular position at La Pine Middle School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the .5 FTE Assistant Wrestling Coach - La Pine Middle School - Regular prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At La Pine Middle School, the .5 FTE Assistant Wrestling Coach - La Pine Middle School - Regular works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The .5 FTE Assistant Wrestling Coach - La Pine Middle School - Regular encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the .5 FTE Assistant Wrestling Coach - La Pine Middle School - Regular at La Pine Middle School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: 1.0 FTE Head Men's Volleyball Coach - Bend Senior High School - Regular
Job.JobDescription: The Boys' Volleyball Coach is responsible for developing, organizing, and leading a comprehensive volleyball program that fosters athletic skill development, teamwork, sportsmanship, and personal growth among student-athletes. The coach plans and conducts practices, teaches fundamental and advanced techniques, and ensures a safe, positive, and inclusive environment that supports both competitive excellence and educational values. The coach works in coordination with school, district, and statewide athletic policies to manage all aspects of the program, including scheduling, communication with families, and supervision of assistant coaches and players. The Boys' Volleyball Coach serves as a mentor and role model for student-athletes, promoting academic achievement, character development, and respect within the team, school, and community.

Job.JobTitle: 2026-2027 Head Varsity Boy's Soccer Coach - Springfield High School
Head Cross Country Coach - Springfield High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Cross Country Coach - Springfield High School role at Springfield High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Head Cross Country Coach - Springfield High School is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Springfield High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Head Cross Country Coach - Springfield High School listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Head Cross Country Coach - Springfield High School encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Head Cross Country Coach - Springfield High School follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Springfield High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Head Cross Country Coach - Springfield High School at Springfield High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Assistant Track Coach - Wilsonville High School This position timeline is from March 2, 2026 through March 29, 2026.
West Linn High School seeks a highly qualified individual to serve as an Assistant Track & Field Coach with the expertise in hurdles, pole vault, throws (discus, javelin, shot put), jumps (high, long, triple), or a combination thereof.
Community and District Information: The West Linn-Wilsonville School District is nestled within two thriving cities, West Linn and Wilsonville, within the rural area of Clackamas County. Both communities have a strong legacy of support for their schools, music and arts endeavors, and the overall well-being of their patrons. The school district and surrounding communities have experienced steady, constant growth over the past three decades. The estimated student population of the District as of December 2024 is 8,900.
It is the policy of the West Linn-Wilsonville Board of Education and School District (WLWV) that no discrimination or harassment on the grounds of race, color, national origin, religion, sex, sexual orientation, age, marital status, veterans' status, genetic information, or disability shall occur if the employee with or without reasonable accommodation, is able to perform the essential functions of the position. These protections apply to students, employees, and other members of the public. West Linn-Wilsonville School District is committed to equal access and equal opportunity in all activities/services, educational programs, and employment. Persons having questions regarding equal opportunity and nondiscrimination should contact the Director of Human Resources at the West Linn-Wilsonville School District, 503-673-7095.

The Coach, Assistant Track - RHS role at Riverside High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Coach, Assistant Track - RHS is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Riverside High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Coach, Assistant Track - RHS sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Riverside High School, the Coach, Assistant Track - RHS is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Coach, Assistant Track - RHS at Riverside High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobDescription:
Position Title: Middle School Head Coach
Reports To: Director of Athletics & High School Head Coach
Salary: Stipend (set by coaches pay scale)
POSITION GOAL:
The successful candidate will be responsible for creating a safe and positive atmosphere that welcomes and respects all individuals while promoting and maintaining safe conditions in accordance with PIAA, league, sports medicine and RSD policies/procedures. Furthermore the candidate will be responsible for instilling Red Knight pride, connecting with youth programs, teaching education through athletics, fundraising.
QUALIFICATIONS:
Must be a minimum age of 18 years old. High School Diploma or equivalent required. Preferable experience working in a supervision role in athletics, recreation, education, or related fields. Exceptional interpersonal skills including the ability to effectively communicate with adults and students in a diverse work environment.
ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS:

Position Title: Youth Swim/Dive Assistant Coach Reports To: Assistant Athletic Director for Aquatics & High School Head Coach Salary: Stipend (set by coaches pay scale) POSITION GOAL: The successful candidate will be responsible for creating a safe and positive atmosphere that welcomes and respects all individuals while promoting and maintaining safe conditions in accordance with governing bodies, league, sports medicine and RSD policies/procedures. Furthermore the candidate will be responsible for instilling Red Knight pride, teaching education through athletics, and fundraising. QUALIFICATIONS: Must be a minimum age of 18 years old. High School Diploma or equivalent required. Preferable experience working in a supervision role in athletics, recreation, education, or related fields. Exceptional interpersonal skills including the ability to effectively communicate with adults and students in a diverse work environment. Current lifeguard certification or willingness to obtain. ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS: 1. Supervise student-athletes 2. Stay current with current rules, coaching techniques, schemes, and best practices 3. Monitor student-athletes to prevent accidents and injuries. 4. Place student-athletes in positions to succeed not only in their sport, but also in life 5. Demonstrate strong interpersonal skills including communication skills with sports medicine staff, game workers, officials, media, students, parents, spectators, and facility staff. 6. Ensures that all possible safety measures are observed, including taking proper care of equipment and proper surveillance of program participants. 7. Attend all training sessions and any additional staff meetings. 8. Work flexible hours including, early mornings, afternoon/evenings, weekends, and holidays. 9. Verify student-athletes are eligible by governing bodies and Reading School District Athletic policies. 10. Secure equipment and facilities after each usage 11. Communicate with RSD admin, safe schools, custodial services and/or RPD as needed. 12. Be a good role model to student-athletes 13. Distribute, collect and track uniforms/equipment 14. Support all RSD athletics PHYSICAL REQUIREMENTS: Physically perform all skills required of a coach. Hear noises and distress signals in a crowded athletic facility. Able to withstand extreme weather conditions Able to lift at least 20 pounds.
Job.Experience: Preferable

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track at STETSON MIDDLE SCH is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.

The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Job.JobDescription:
The Head HS Boys Soccer Coach position at Chambersburg Senior High provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Head HS Boys Soccer Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Chambersburg Senior High, the Head HS Boys Soccer Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Head HS Boys Soccer Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Head HS Boys Soccer Coach at Chambersburg Senior High is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobDescription:
The Lacrosse Assistant Coach-Girls at Red Land High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Lacrosse Assistant Coach-Girls is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Red Land High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Lacrosse Assistant Coach-Girls helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Lacrosse Assistant Coach-Girls works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Red Land High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Red Land High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Lacrosse Assistant Coach-Girls reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Lacrosse Assistant Coach-Girls role at Red Land High School.

This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Job.JobDescription:
Under direction of the school principal at Classical High School and the Athletic Director/or appropriate supervisor/ Administrator, Individuals will be available three hours each day during the entire season.
This position is contingent upon the following:
Preference will be given to internal/school based staff and co-op school staff. Successful recruitment of team members and ability to field a team for practice and game conditions. Proper physical conditioning related to the sport during practice sessions. Successful completion of the interscholastic season You must complete the new hire compliance training prior to your first day of employment Bilingual Preferred Selected candidate will be required to pass a pre-employment criminal history background check. Selected candidates cannot begin work until passing their background check.
Salary Rate Range: 10% of Teacher Salary Scale
EDUCATION REQUIREMENTS:
RIDE Requirements: Must be certified in accordance with the new RIIL Coaching Permit Requirements
Qualifications:
BA in education or related field preferred but not required. Have current CPR/First Aid Certification in possession (required) Principles of Coaching. Psychology of Coaching. Athletic Training (Prevention and care of athletic injuries). Bio-mechanics (Analysis and understanding of human movement). Previous playing and coaching experience preferred. Dedication to the service of youth and ability to gain and hold the respect of team members.
DESCRIPTION OF DUTIES & RESPONSIBILITIES:
Teach fundamentals and skills. Organize practice sessions. Keep records and report results to local media. Provide Principal and Athletic Director an outline of a general practice session. Conduct coaches meetings and assign coaches responsibilities. Provide for care and prevention of injuries. Conform to all rules established by the Principal’s Committee on Athletics and perform duties in accordance with the Providence School Department Athletic Handbook. Teach rules and regulations of the sport. Display good sportsmanship at all times. Responsible for the issuing, maintaining, and collecting of equipment. Prepare team budget. Recruitment of players and advancement of the sport.
Position Type: Part-Time Salary: $4,834 to $9,112 Per Year
Job Requirements
Citizenship, residency or work visa required
Job.Location: Classical High School - Providence, Rhode Island

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Boys' Volleyball Coach position at Cranston High School West is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Assistant Boys' Volleyball Coach role at Cranston High School West is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Serving as the ADJUNCT COACH - TRACK & FIELD THROWERS COACH FOR SY 2025 at Riverside High allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobTitle: Adjunct Coach - Softball Asst Varsity Coach with CDL preferred for SY 2025-2026
Job.JobDescription:
The Adjunct Coach - Softball Asst Varsity Coach with CDL preferred for SY 2025 position at Riverside High is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Adjunct Coach - Softball Asst Varsity Coach with CDL preferred for SY 2025 works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Adjunct Coach - Softball Asst Varsity Coach with CDL preferred for SY 2025 at Riverside High sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Riverside High, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Adjunct Coach - Softball Asst Varsity Coach with CDL preferred for SY 2025 encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Adjunct Coach - Softball Asst Varsity Coach with CDL preferred for SY 2025 is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Adjunct Coach - Softball Asst Varsity Coach with CDL preferred for SY 2025 position at Riverside High is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobTitle: Adjunct Coach Girls Distance Track Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Adjunct Coach Girls Distance Track Coach at J.L. Mann High is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Adjunct Coach Girls Distance Track Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at J.L. Mann High reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Adjunct Coach Girls Distance Track Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Adjunct Coach Girls Distance Track Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Adjunct Coach Girls Distance Track Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at J.L. Mann High. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

The Varsity Football - Assistant Coaches Coach at Southside High is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Varsity Football - Assistant Coaches Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Southside High use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Varsity Football - Assistant Coaches Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Varsity Football - Assistant Coaches Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Varsity Football - Assistant Coaches Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Southside High. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

The Adjunct Coach Assistant Wrestling Coach 2025 role at J.L. Mann High is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Adjunct Coach Assistant Wrestling Coach 2025 is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at J.L. Mann High are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Adjunct Coach Assistant Wrestling Coach 2025 listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Adjunct Coach Assistant Wrestling Coach 2025 encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Adjunct Coach Assistant Wrestling Coach 2025 follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At J.L. Mann High, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Adjunct Coach Assistant Wrestling Coach 2025 at J.L. Mann High, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

The Adjunct Coach Track (Sprinters) at J.L. Mann High is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Adjunct Coach Track (Sprinters) manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At J.L. Mann High, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Adjunct Coach Track (Sprinters) demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Adjunct Coach Track (Sprinters) follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Adjunct Coach Track (Sprinters) at J.L. Mann High allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

The Adjunct Coach Track (Thrower) position at J.L. Mann High is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Adjunct Coach Track (Thrower) is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At J.L. Mann High, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Adjunct Coach Track (Thrower) encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Adjunct Coach Track (Thrower) also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Adjunct Coach Track (Thrower) role at J.L. Mann High is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Head JV Girls Soccer Coach - Philip Simmons High
Job.JobDescription: Position Type: Temporary Employees/Athletic Coaches Date Posted: 1/26/2026 Location: Philip Simmons High Closing Date: 02/26/2026 Education and Experience: Bachelor's degree or higher preferred with 3 years coaching experience preferred. Temporary Employee Application Requirements Required documents must be scanned and uploaded. Documents will not be accepted otherwise. Complete and submit online application along with the required documents listed below: Resume BCSD requires a negative Tuberculosis Test Result before employment begins. Negative TB test result less than 1 year old - upload if available or upload statement will provide at New Hire Orientation. Current BCSD employees - upload this statement. TB test result must be submitted at new hire orientation (no exceptions).
Job.Experience: 3 years coaching experience preferred

Job.JobDescription: Richland County School District One, South Carolina Classification Description Classification Title: Supplemental Coach Job Summary: We are seeking a dynamic, passionate, and skilled Supplemental Athletic Coach to assist in the development and coaching of student-athletes in various sports programs. This position will focus on enhancing individual and team performance, supporting the head coach, and promoting a positive and inclusive athletic environment. The Supplemental Athletic Coach will work closely with athletes, coaches, and staff to help guide students toward their full potential, both in sport and personal development. Key Responsibilities: Assist the head coach with planning and implementing daily practice sessions, drills, and team strategies. Provide individualized coaching and support to athletes to help improve their technical skills, athletic performance, and teamwork. Foster a positive and motivating atmosphere that encourages the growth and development of all student-athletes. Evaluate athlete performance and provide constructive feedback to improve skills, strength, and conditioning. Support the organization and management of game-day operations, including warm-ups, player preparation, and team logistics. Collaborate with coaching staff to set team goals and help track progress toward those goals. Assist in the monitoring of athlete eligibility, attendance, and participation requirements. Ensure that all practices and events comply with relevant regulations, rules, and school policies. Help maintain and organize athletic equipment and ensure the safety of all participants during training and events. Serve as a mentor and role model, promoting sportsmanship, leadership, and respect for others. Communicate regularly with parents and guardians regarding athlete progress and team matters. Contribute to the recruitment of new athletes and support the retention of current team members. Qualifications: Previous coaching experience in the relevant sport (1-3 years preferred). Knowledge of sport-specific techniques, rules, and strategies. Ability to communicate effectively with athletes, parents, staff, and administration. Strong organizational and time-management skills. A commitment to promoting a positive and inclusive team environment. CPR and First Aid certification (or willingness to obtain). High school diploma or equivalent (Bachelor's degree in Physical Education, Sports Management, or a related field is a plus). Ability to work flexible hours, including evenings and weekends, as needed. Desired Skills & Abilities: Strong interpersonal and motivational skills to connect with athletes. Ability to adapt coaching techniques to the needs and skill levels of individual athletes. Experience with strength and conditioning, as well as injury prevention and rehabilitation. Enthusiasm for teaching and mentoring young athletes. Knowledge of current trends in sports coaching and athlete development. Physical Requirements: Ability to participate in physical activities such as drills, conditioning, and demonstrations.

Physical Requirements: Ability to participate in physical activities such as drills, conditioning, and demonstrations. Ability to lift and carry athletic equipment and materials. This position will focus on enhancing individual and team performance, supporting the head coach, and promoting a positive and inclusive athletic environment.
