The Varsity Baseball Coach role at Mt. Healthy Jr/Sr High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Varsity Baseball Coach is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Mt. Healthy Jr/Sr High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Varsity Baseball Coach sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Mt. Healthy Jr/Sr High School, the Varsity Baseball Coach is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Varsity Baseball Coach at Mt. Healthy Jr/Sr High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job Summary Ross Local School District is seeking a qualified and motivated individual to serve as the Varsity Boys Head Soccer Coach at Ross High School. The Head Coach is responsible for leading and managing all aspects of the varsity boys soccer program, while promoting academic achievement, sportsmanship, and the overall development of student-athletes in alignment with district values and OHSAA regulations.
Essential Duties and Responsibilities Plan, organize, and conduct effective practices and training sessions. Lead and supervise all varsity boys' soccer competitions. Develop and maintain a positive and safe team culture. Promote academic success, sportsmanship, and character development among student-athletes. Coordinate and collaborate with the Athletic Director, school administration, and other coaching staff. Support and help develop the overall boys soccer program, including cooperation with middle school and youth programs as appropriate. Ensure compliance with OHSAA, district policies, and league rules and regulations. Communicate effectively with players, parents, staff, and administration. Maintain accurate records, including attendance, eligibility, and equipment inventories. Supervise student-athletes before, during, and after practices and contests.
Qualifications Demonstrated knowledge of soccer fundamentals, strategies, and rules. Previous coaching experience at the high school or competitive club level preferred. Strong leadership, organizational, and communication skills. Ability to positively motivate and mentor student-athletes. Commitment to maintaining high standards of professionalism and ethics.
Required Certifications (the district will guide you through these steps) Valid Ohio Pupil Activity Permit Completion of all OHSAA-required coaching certifications Current CPR/AED and First Aid certification BCI and FBI background checks
Compensation Supplemental coaching stipend per the Ross Local School District negotiated agreement.
Job.Experience: Previous coaching experience at the high school or competitive club level preferred

Job.JobTitle: CHS - Head Bowling Coach/Assistant Bowling Coach - Winter 25-26

Job.JobDescription:
The JV Girls Soccer Coach role at HIGH SCHOOL is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the JV Girls Soccer Coach is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at HIGH SCHOOL are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The JV Girls Soccer Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the JV Girls Soccer Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The JV Girls Soccer Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At HIGH SCHOOL, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the JV Girls Soccer Coach at HIGH SCHOOL, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

The Anticipated Head Football Coach at Tiffin Columbian High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Anticipated Head Football Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Tiffin Columbian High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Anticipated Head Football Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Anticipated Head Football Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Anticipated Head Football Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Tiffin Columbian High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

GRANVILLE EXEMPTED VILLAGE SCHOOL DISTRICT JOB DESCRIPTION
Title: ASSISTANT COACH
Reports to: Head Coach
Job Objective: Uses technical expertise to coach the assigned athletic activity.
Minimum Qualifications:
Complies with drug-free workplace rules and board policies. Relevant coaching experience. Knowledgeable about interscholastic athletic program regulations. Completion of state activity supervisory permit requirements (e.g., first aid/CPR, etc.). Meets all mandated health requirements. A record free of criminal violations that would prohibit public school employment.
NOTE: Supplemental contracts are offered to qualified certificated staff with appropriate training, knowledge, and experience. Unfilled positions may be offered to other suitable applicants meeting department of education permit requirements.
Essential Functions: The following are typical work responsibilities. A reasonable accommodation may be made to enable a qualified individual with a disability to perform essential functions.
Works with student athletes to improve personal and teamwork skills. Provides guidance and encouragement to help students benefit from participation in program activities. Upholds board policies and follows administrative guidelines/procedures. Promotes a professional image of the school district. Encourages community partnerships that enhance district programs. Promotes effective communications and assistance. Uses problem-solving techniques to tactfully address questions/concerns. Refers policy interpretation inquiries to administrative staff. Reviews procedures and schedules before the start of the season. Consults with the head coach to evaluate program needs. Promotes the proper use, care, and security of school property. Attends all mandatory programs (e.g., rules interpretation, safety clinics, etc.). Monitors innovations, evaluates activities, and recommends program improvements. Helps coordinate the development of off-season activities (e.g., summer training, clinics, etc.). Helps parents and students understand program objectives. Explains student responsibilities (e.g., scholastic eligibility, permission forms, medical exams, activity schedules, letters, awards, participation certificates, insurance coverage, waiver forms, etc.). Encourages student involvement in program activities. Helps verify medical/scholastic eligibility. Promotes academic success as an important priority for all students. Helps organize team tryouts. Helps maintain the integrity of the selection process. Carries out the assigned practice schedule. Gives the head coach a copy of all student communications. Helps ensure that all athletes receive appropriate instruction, support, and opportunities to participate. Helps assign and track equipment issued to staff and students. Helps supervise the preparation of athletic fields and practice/training areas as directed. Teaches precautions and procedures to help students prevent injuries. Ensures that equipment is appropriate for participants’ physical development and skill level. Helps ensure that all required medical authorizations forms are on file and readily available. Documents all injuries that require treatment. Helps evaluate individual/team performance. Helps develop/refine game strategies. Helps recruit, train, and supervise student managers, trainers, and scouts. Helps the activities director secure personnel for home games when requested. Upholds the student conduct code. Implements effective pupil management procedures. Models behavior that demonstrates respect for rules, officials, and opponents. Ensures that participant communications do not demean or ridicule mistakes and/or performance. Helps arrange transportation and accompanies the team to sanctioned athletic activities. Obtains permission to be away when duties conflict with other assigned duties. Provides guidance, communicates expectations, and shows an active interest in student progress. Participates in athletic recognition programs. Helps verify that participants have fulfilled all requirements for letters, awards, and/or participation certificates.

The Norwalk Middle School Track Coaches (2) role at Norwalk Middle School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Norwalk Middle School Track Coaches (2) coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Norwalk Middle School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Norwalk Middle School Track Coaches (2) reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Norwalk Middle School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Norwalk Middle School Track Coaches (2) may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Norwalk Middle School Track Coaches (2) monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Norwalk Middle School Track Coaches (2) must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Norwalk Middle School.

The Girls Golf - Head Coach at Mr. Matt Spellman is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Girls Golf - Head Coach manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Mr. Matt Spellman, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Girls Golf - Head Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Girls Golf - Head Coach follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Girls Golf - Head Coach at Mr. Matt Spellman allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.
Job.Experience: Coaching experience preferred

Job.JobDescription:
The Middle School Softball Coach position at Kaci Matthews or Kregg Creamer is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Middle School Softball Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Kaci Matthews or Kregg Creamer, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Middle School Softball Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Middle School Softball Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Middle School Softball Coach role at Kaci Matthews or Kregg Creamer is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: High School Boys JV Golf Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The High School Boys JV Golf Coach role at Kregg Creamer is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the High School Boys JV Golf Coach is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Kregg Creamer are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The High School Boys JV Golf Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the High School Boys JV Golf Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The High School Boys JV Golf Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Kregg Creamer, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the High School Boys JV Golf Coach at Kregg Creamer, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Application must be completed to be considered.
TITLE: Assistant Athletic Coach - Supplemental position
SUGGESTED
QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Valid driver's license.
REPORTS TO: Head Coach, Athletic Director, Principal and/or Designee SALARY: Supplemental as per negotiated agreement POSITION GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self discipline, self confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc. SUPERVISES: The assistant coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of coaches at the high school and middle school level in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal. 1.0 PROFESSIONAL & PERSONAL RELATIONSHIPS 1.01 Assists the head coach in regard to submitting participant lists, bus times, parent permission, physical cards, year-end reports and program information relative to your sport. 1.02 Follows policy in the Athletic Handbook and meets all criteria as outlined in the job description. 1.03 Provides training rules to team members in writing and follows due process procedures. 1.04 Develops rapport with the athletic coaching staff. 1.05 Participates in in-service meetings and other activities to improve coaching performance. Attends meetings necessary to the welfare of the Athletic Department. 1.06 Develops sound public relations. Co-operates with newspapers, radio, T.V., Booster Club, and interested spectators. Upholds the integrity of the athletic program by refraining from making negative remarks. 1.07 Maintains suitable sideline conduct at games. Expects sportsmanlike behavior to be displayed by assistant coaches and athletes toward all individuals involved with the contest (officials, workers, fans, etc.). 1.08 Serves as a role model to players, coaches and spectators in demonstrating good sportsmanship and ethical behavior at all times. 1.09 Demonstrates respect for opponents before, during and after the contest. Displays modesty in victory and graciousness in defeat. 1.10 Works cooperatively with junior high coaches in developing a coordinated program. 1.11 Works cooperatively with Head Coach and Athletic Director and completes duties assigned to them 2.09 Shows an interest in athletes in off-season activities and classroom efforts. 2.10 Delegates authority with responsibility while remaining accountable for such delegations. 2.11 Team performance consistent with quality of athletes available. 2.12 Supervision of players in the locker room, practice, field, bus and other areas. 3. RELATED COACHING RESPONSIBILITIES 3.01 Is concerned about the care of equipment, including issue, collection, inventory and storage. 3.02 Is cooperative in preparation of non-league scheduling. 3.03 Is cooperative in helping service clubs, Booster Club, Recreation Department and other organizations in their projects, which in turn relate to our athletic program. 3.04 Follows proper procedure for purchase of equipment. 3.05 Operates sport within the budget as submitted.

The Assistant Boys Tennis Coach position at Jonathan Alder High School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Assistant Boys Tennis Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Assistant Boys Tennis Coach at Jonathan Alder High School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Jonathan Alder High School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Assistant Boys Tennis Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Assistant Boys Tennis Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Assistant Boys Tennis Coach position at Jonathan Alder High School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

HEAD VOLLEYBALL COACH – POSITION POSTING
Indian Hill Exempted Village School District To Apply: Email Brian Phelps, Athletic Director, with a resume and letter of interest. POSITION: Head Volleyball Coach
LOCATION: Indian Hill High School
STARTING DATE: Spring 2026 Season
CATEGORY: Supplemental
REPORTS TO: Athletic Director
STATUS: FLSA Exempt; Section 3319.02 – ORC
GENERAL DESCRIPTION Indian Hill High School is ready to welcome an inspiring leader to take the helm of a volleyball program bursting with potential, energy, and pride. Our student-athletes are competitive, committed, and hungry to grow — and they thrive in a district where excellence isn’t just encouraged, it’s expected. As the Head Volleyball Coach, you’ll shape a program that blends high-level skill development with culture-building, leadership, and the kind of team chemistry that makes something magical happen on and off the court.
This is your chance to build a marquee volleyball experience in one of Ohio’s most admired school districts — a place where families are supportive, the athletic department is collaborative, and student-athletes buy in fully to the vision of a coach who leads with purpose. From practice strategy to game-day intensity, you’ll have the opportunity to elevate the entire program and create moments that athletes and fans will remember for years. If fueling competitive success, developing strong young leaders, and building a program rooted in heart, grit, and high expectations excites you — Indian Hill is ready for you to lead the charge.
Indian Hill High School is a high-achieving Division II athletic program serving approximately 650 students in grades 9-12. Candidates must possess all required Ohio Department of Education coaching credentials and successfully complete FBI/BCI background checks.
PREFERRED SKILLS
• Prior volleyball coaching experience preferred
• Understanding of systems, player development, and strategy
• Ability to build positive team culture

This is a standout opportunity to shape the future of field hockey in one of Ohio’s most respected school districts, known for its supportive families, exceptional student-athletes, and a collaborative athletic department that embraces innovation. Whether it’s building fundamentals, designing a game plan that fires up your team, or creating traditions that bring the school community together, you’ll make a lasting impact in a role full of purpose and possibility.
If you’re fueled by developing confident competitors, building a cohesive team culture, and leading a program that reflects heart, hustle, and excellence — Indian Hill is ready for your leadership.

The Varsity Boys Golf - Head Coach at Trey Newberry is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Varsity Boys Golf - Head Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Trey Newberry, the Varsity Boys Golf - Head Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Varsity Boys Golf - Head Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Trey Newberry well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Varsity Boys Golf - Head Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

At Trey Newberry, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Varsity Softball Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The Varsity Softball Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Coach Boys Varsity Wrestling at Trey Newberry is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Assistant Coach Boys Varsity Wrestling plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Trey Newberry reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Assistant Coach Boys Varsity Wrestling expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Assistant Coach Boys Varsity Wrestling supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Assistant Coach Boys Varsity Wrestling may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Trey Newberry. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobDescription:
The Anticipated Golf Assistant Coach position at Red Land High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Anticipated Golf Assistant Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Red Land High School, the Anticipated Golf Assistant Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Anticipated Golf Assistant Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Anticipated Golf Assistant Coach at Red Land High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobDescription:
The 7th and 8th Grade Baseball Coaches role at Mr. David Lloyd is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the 7th and 8th Grade Baseball Coaches is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Mr. David Lloyd, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The 7th and 8th Grade Baseball Coaches sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Mr. David Lloyd, the 7th and 8th Grade Baseball Coaches is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the 7th and 8th Grade Baseball Coaches at Mr. David Lloyd is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.
Job.CompanyDescription: Lower Merion School District coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The 7th Grade Softball Coach at Lower Merion School District is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the 7th Grade Softball Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Lower Merion School District use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The 7th Grade Softball Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the 7th Grade Softball Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The 7th Grade Softball Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Lower Merion School District. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
The Pennridge School District is seeking applicants for the position of Assistant Coach for the Unified Bocce team. The assistant coach is responsible for assisting the head coach with the organization and administration of the athletic program.
Key Responsibilities: Assist the Head Coach with planning and leading practices and competitions. Support the development of student-athletes' skills, teamwork, and sportsmanship. Promote academic achievement and personal growth among athletes. Assist with supervision and safety of all team members during activities. Help manage equipment and maintain team standards of conduct. Model positive behavior and represent the school in a professional manner. Follow all school, district, league, and state athletic association rules.
Minimum Qualifications: High school diploma or equivalent. Some coaching or playing experience in the sport (preferably at the high school level). Basic understanding of the game, rules, and strategy. Strong communication and interpersonal skills. Ability to work collaboratively with the Head Coach and school staff.
Preferred Qualifications: CPR/First Aid certification. NFHS coaching certification or willingness to obtain. Experience working with youth or student-athletes. Familiarity with school athletic program policies and procedures.
Pre-Employment Paperwork Requirements: Physical and Clearances must be dated within the last 12-months. TB test within the last 90-days. PA State Police Clearance (Act 34) Child Abuse Clearance (Act 151) FBI Fingerprint Clearance (Act 114) School Personnel Health Form (Physical and TB test) PDE 6004 Form (Act 24) Sexual Misconduct/Abuse Disclosure Release Form(s) (Act 168)
Procedure: Interested candidates applying for the above position should submit an online application.
Job Requirements: High School/Trade School degree preferred. Citizenship, residency or work visa required

The Girls Track Coach at Indian Crest Middle School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Girls Track Coach manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Indian Crest Middle School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Girls Track Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Girls Track Coach follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Girls Track Coach at Indian Crest Middle School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobDescription:
The Aquarettes Advisor at Senior High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Aquarettes Advisor is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Senior High School, the Aquarettes Advisor helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Aquarettes Advisor may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Senior High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Aquarettes Advisor follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Assistant Boys Soccer Coaches (2) - PWHS manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Plymouth Whitemarsh High School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Assistant Boys Soccer Coaches (2) - PWHS demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Assistant Boys Soccer Coaches (2) - PWHS follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Assistant Boys Soccer Coaches (2) - PWHS at Plymouth Whitemarsh High School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobDescription:
The Ultimate Frisbee Coach - PWHS at Colonial is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Ultimate Frisbee Coach - PWHS is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Colonial, the Ultimate Frisbee Coach - PWHS helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Ultimate Frisbee Coach - PWHS may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Colonial well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Ultimate Frisbee Coach - PWHS follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobTitle: First Aid Responder - Colonial Middle School
Job.JobDescription:
The First Aid Responder - Colonial Middle School role at Colonial is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the First Aid Responder - Colonial Middle School is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Colonial, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The First Aid Responder - Colonial Middle School sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Colonial, the First Aid Responder - Colonial Middle School is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the First Aid Responder - Colonial Middle School at Colonial is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

The Assistant Track Coach - PWHS position at Colleen Techtmann provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Assistant Track Coach - PWHS prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Colleen Techtmann, the Assistant Track Coach - PWHS works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Assistant Track Coach - PWHS encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Assistant Track Coach - PWHS at Colleen Techtmann is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

The Assistant Softball Coach - PWHS at Colleen Techtmann is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Assistant Softball Coach - PWHS are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Colleen Techtmann use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Assistant Softball Coach - PWHS recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Assistant Softball Coach - PWHS collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Assistant Softball Coach - PWHS maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Colleen Techtmann. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

The Ultimate Frisbee - PWHS role at Colonial is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Ultimate Frisbee - PWHS is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Colonial are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Ultimate Frisbee - PWHS listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Ultimate Frisbee - PWHS encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Ultimate Frisbee - PWHS follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Colonial, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Ultimate Frisbee - PWHS at Colonial, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

The Head Middle School Field Hockey Coach is responsible for leading and developing a program that fosters skill growth, teamwork, and a love for the game. This role involves creating a positive, inclusive, and structured environment where student-athletes can build confidence, sportsmanship, and a strong work ethic. The head coach will know the rules of the game and instruct participants using current and appropriate coaching methods and strategies that promote good health and safety practices, physical fitness, sportsmanship, and skill development. Primary Duties and Responsibilities: Promote, select, supervise and instruct student-athletes on accordance with established District, Conference and PIAA standards and regulations. Team selection is subject to the Athletic Director's review and approval. Know the rules of the game and instruct participants using current and appropriate coaching methods and strategies that promote good health and safety practices, physical fitness, sportsmanship, and skill development. Project a positive model for student-athletes, the general student body, and the community at large through appearance, positive attitude and enthusiastic personality, emotional maturity, self-control, leadership, planning, preparation and good sportsmanship. Maintain effective communications with students, parents, staff, administration, the media and higher institutions of higher education. Explain the expectations of the head coach to each assistant coach as it pertains to performance and the evaluation of performance. Conduct and attend meetings as mandated by the PIAA, the Conference, and as assigned by the Athletic Director or assigned principal. Plan and schedule, in coordination with the Athletic Director, all practices and recommend use of facilities. Maintain accurate and timely records as mandated by the PIAA, the Conference, and as directed by the Athletic Director. Acquire and maintain First Aid and CPR certification yearly (provided by Central York School District), and administer emergency treatment of injuries in the absence of a trainer, physician, or other person more qualified than him/herself. Safeguard all equipment and facilities to assure safety and proper use. Maintain an up-to-date and accurate inventory of all equipment and supplies used in the sport. Annually prepare and submit a detailed requisition for equipment and supplies needed for the following year to the Athletic Director. Promote positive self-esteem and climate among all participants and provide for appropriate recognition of student-athlete achievement in accordance with District, Conference and PIAA standards and practices. Promote appropriate use of language. Complete additional duties as assigned by the Athletic Director or assigned principal Where: Central York Middle School 1950 North Hills Road York, PA 17406 Qualifications: * Combination of education and experience necessary to perform the tasks outlined in this job description * Must have ( or willing ot obtain) current PA Criminal, PA Child Abuse and FBI Fingerprint History Background Clearances.

The High School Track Assistant Coach – Throws plays a critical role in supporting the growth and development of student-athletes through dedication, teamwork, and discipline. Working closely with the head coach, the throws coach helps implement strategic direction, technique development, and motivation within the track program while promoting a culture of excellence, inclusion, and sportsmanship. Responsibilities include assisting with practice planning, teaching proper throwing techniques, preparing athletes for meets, and maintaining a positive and respectful team environment. The throws coach supports athletes in striving for success both on and off the field, helping them build confidence, leadership, and lifelong values through the sport of track and field. Primary Duties and Responsibilities: * Function within the philosophy and objectives developed by the District's interscholastic athletic programs as well as within guidelines available in the Co-Curricular Manual and in building manuals. * Enhance coaching skills through subscription to professional journals, membership in professional associations and attendance at clinics. * Administer emergency treatment of injuries in the absence of a trainer, physician or other person more qualified than him/herself. * Project a positive model for student-athletes, the general student body, and the community at large through appearance, positive attitude, enthusiastic personality, emotional maturity, self-control, leadership, planning, preparation, and good sportsmanship. * Teach each athlete skills necessary for the appropriate position in the sport, using proven and up-to date coaching techniques. * Maintain total loyalty, support of, and communication with the head coach and program while assisting the former in physical, mental and skills preparation of the student-athletes. * Apply disciplinary procedures fairly and in concert with those of the head coach, school and District. * Effectively utilize practice time allotted by the head coach in the prescribed manner to further individual and team performance. * Complete additional duties as assigned by the Athletic Director or assigned principal. Where: Central York High School 601 Mundis Mill Road York, PA 17406 Qualifications: * Combination of education and experience necessary to perform the tasks outlined in this job description * Must have ( or willing ot obtain) current PA Criminal, PA Child Abuse and FBI Fingerprint History Background Clearances.

The Boys Outdoor Track - Head Coach at William Tennent High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Boys Outdoor Track - Head Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at William Tennent High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Boys Outdoor Track - Head Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Boys Outdoor Track - Head Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Boys Outdoor Track - Head Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at William Tennent High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.
