Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS position at Henderson High School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Henderson High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS role at Henderson High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.
Job.Location: Henderson High School, West Chester, Pennsylvania
Job.CompanyDescription: West Chester Area School D. coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track at Stetson Middle School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Stetson Middle School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Stetson Middle School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Stetson Middle School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track role at Stetson Middle School.
Job.Location: Stetson Middle School, West Chester, Pennsylvania
Job.CompanyDescription: West Chester Area School D. coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription: Position Type: ATHLETICS / ACTIVITIES Date Posted: 10/1/2025 Location: Eastside High School-Athletics Date Available: 03/09/2026 Closing Date: 03/09/2026 Effective Date (s): March 9, 2026 - June 6, 2026 Staff Needed: One (1) Strength and Conditioning Coach Qualifications: • DOE Certification Requirements (including volunteer coaches) must have one of the two certifications: o New Jersey Teacher’s Certification o New Jersey Instructional Substitute Credential (30 College Credits) • Proof of experience required for Substitute Certificate holder. • Coaching experience preferred but not required. • Must be available daily during the winter sports season. • All coaches must hold a current (valid) adult CPR/AED and Basic First Aid Certification. • All courses that the DOE approves for certification are acceptable. • All new coaches (starting 2007-2008 school year) must complete the NFHS Fundamentals of Coaching Course before their first employment as a coach. This course is a one-time requirement. • All coaches must complete the NFHS Concussion in Sports Course, renewed annually. • All coaches must complete the NFHS Heat Illness Prevention Course, renewed annually. • All coaches must complete the NFHS Implicit Bias Course. This course is a one-time requirement. • All coaches must complete the BeNice Program. This course is a one-time requirement. Salary: $1,845.00 - $3,051.00 Initiator: Tororris J. Hill, Athletic Supervisor • Meet such alternatives to the above qualifications as the Superintendent may find appropriate and acceptable. • Pending budget availability. • All postings are open for ten (10) consecutive days following the date posted or until filled.

Effective Date(s): March 9, 2026 - June 15, 2026 Staff Needed: Two (2) Assistant Coach Softball Qualifications:
* New Jersey Teacher's Certificate OR Substitute Teacher Certificate; proof of experience required for substitute certificate holder * Coaching experience preferred, but not required * Must be available daily during the fall sports season * Must be certified in CPR and AED, and holding a current certificate in both * Must obtain a "Concussion Awareness and Wellness" certificate or its equivalent, renewed annually * Must Obtain a "Heat Acclimatization Awareness and Wellness" certificate or it's equivalent, renewed annually. * All new coaches will have one year after being hired to successfully complete a course in "Sports First Aid".

This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Assistant Coach - Boys Spring Track is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Woodbridge High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Assistant Coach - Boys Spring Track encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. The Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball role at John F. Kennedy Memorial High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at John F. Kennedy Memorial High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At John F. Kennedy Memorial High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Anticipated Assistant Coach - Boys Volleyball at John F. Kennedy Memorial High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
The Anticipated Head Coach - Football role at John F. Kennedy Memorial High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Anticipated Head Coach - Football is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At John F. Kennedy Memorial High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Anticipated Head Coach - Football sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At John F. Kennedy Memorial High School, the Anticipated Head Coach - Football is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Anticipated Head Coach - Football at John F. Kennedy Memorial High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.
Job.Location: John F. Kennedy Memorial High School

Job.CompanyName: John F. Kennedy Memorial High School

Job.JobDescription:
The Substitute Athletic Trainers position at Brick Township provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Substitute Athletic Trainers prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Brick Township, the Substitute Athletic Trainers works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Substitute Athletic Trainers encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Substitute Athletic Trainers at Brick Township is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job Description Roswell Independent School District Job Description Job Title: ASSISTANT COACH Reports To: HEAD COACH/PRINCIPAL/DIRECTOR OF ATHLETICS/ACTIVITIES Essential Duties and Responsibilities: 1. Has knowledge of existing system and State and NMAA regulations. 2. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Roswell Independent School District Board of Education and is responsible for their implementation. 3. Has knowledge of the existing system, state and league regulations and implements them consistently. 4. Maintains discipline and works to increase morale and cooperate within the school sports program. 5. Recommends to the head coach budgetary items for next year in his area of the program. 6. Monitors equipment rooms and coaches offices and authorizes who may enter. 7. Is accountable to the head coach for all equipment. Collects the cost of any equipment lost or not returned and arranges for issuing and storing of equipment and submits to the head coach an annual inventory and current records concerning this equipment. 8. Examines locker rooms before and after practices and games, checking on general cleanliness of the facility. Responsible for cleanliness and maintenance of the specific equipment. (and so on, including content from 'ASSISTANT COACH (CONT'D)', 'Qualifications', 'Physical Requirements', 'Safety and Health', 'Equipment/Material Handled', 'Work Environment', and 'Job Requirements' sections) Supervisory Responsibilities: Students in his charge. Qualifications: 1. High School diploma or GED. 2. Current NM Coaching licensure including CPR/AED Certification. 3. Valid Driver's license and Car Insurance. 4. Ability to drive from site to site as needed. Physical Requirements: Sitting, standing, lifting and carrying (up to 40 pounds), climbing stairs, reaching, squatting, kneeling, having full mobility of fingers/hands, and moving light furniture may be required, unless ADA accommodations have been mutually agreed on and does not create an undue hardship upon the district. Safety and Health: Knowledge of universal hygiene precautions (blood borne pathogens, body fluids, etc.) Equipment/Material Handled: Must know how to properly operate, or be willing to learn to operate, multi-media equipment including current technology as needed. Work Environment: Must be able to work within various degrees of noise and temperature. Interruptions of work are routine. Flexibility and patience are required. Must be self-motivated and able to complete job assignments without direct supervision. After hours work may be required. May be required to make home and site visits. May work under stressful conditions on occasion. Terms of Employment: Salary and work year to be established by the Board. Job Requirements: High School/Trade School degree preferred. Citizenship, residency or work visa required
Job.Location: Mesa Middle School - Athletics - Roswell, New Mexico

Job.JobDescription: Roswell Independent School District Job Description Job Title: ASSISTANT COACH Reports To: HEAD COACH/PRINCIPAL/DIRECTOR OF ATHLETICS/ACTIVITIES Essential Duties and Responsibilities: 1. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Roswell Independent School District Board of Education and is responsible for their implementation. 2. Has knowledge of the existing system, state and league regulations and implements them consistently. 3. Maintains discipline and works to increase morale and cooperate within the school sports program. 4. Recommends to the head coach budgetary items for next year in his area of the program. 5. Monitors equipment rooms and coaches offices and authorizes who may enter. 6. Is accountable to the head coach for all equipment. Collects the cost of any equipment lost or not returned and arranges for issuing and storing of equipment and submits to the head coach an annual inventory and current records concerning this equipment. 7. Examines locker rooms before and after practices and games, checking on general cleanliness of the facility. Responsible for cleanliness and maintenance of the specific equipment. 8. Instills in each player a respect for equipment and school property, its care and proper usage. 9. Assist in the necessary preparation to hold scheduled sports events or practices and adheres to scheduled facility times. 10. Coordinates program with maintenance and school employees. 11. Provides proper safeguards for maintenance and protection of assigned equipment sites. Assists the head coach in scheduling, providing transportation to tournaments and special sporting events. 12. Directs student managers and statisticians on respective games. 13. Provides training rules and any other unique regulation of the sport to each athlete who is considered a participant. 14. Determines student discipline, delineates procedures concerning due process when the enforcement of discipline is necessary. 15. By his presence at all practices, games and while traveling, provides assistance and guidance to and safeguards for each participant. 16. Instructs team members as to changes in the rules and teaches fundamentals of the sport as outlined by the head coach. 17. Assists the head coach in carrying out his responsibility. 18. Attends all staff meetings and carries out scouting assignments as outlined by the head coach. 19. Works within the basic framework and philosophy of the head coach of that sport. 20. Arrives early enough before practice, contests and meetings to adequately prepare and remains long enough afterwards to help players with problems or to become involved in staff discussions. 21. Never criticizes, admonishes or argues with head coach or any staff member within ears or eyes of players or parents. 22. Helps in the planning and implementation of both in-season and out-or-season conditioning and weight programs as is possible. 23. Attends most of the contests, when possible, or other teams in the program. 24. Strives to improve skills by attending clinics and using resources made available by the head coach. 25. Performs such other duties that are consistent with the nature of the position and that may be requested by the head coach. 26. Maintain confidentiality with sensitive matters. 27. Be flexible and able to prioritize tasks and maintain accurate and detailed records. 28. Report to work on time and evening /weekend hours are applicable. 29. Attempt to deescalate students/parents/staff; listening/visiting with them about their concerns prior to them meeting with administrators. Supervisory Responsibilities: Students in his charge. Ability to drive from site to site as needed. Work Environment: Must be able to work within various degrees of noise and temperature. Interruptions of work are routine. Flexibility and patience are required. Must be self-motivated and able to complete job assignments without direct supervision. After hours work may be required. May be required to make home and site visits. May work under stressful conditions on occasion. Terms of Employment: Salary and work year to be established by the Board. Roswell Independent School District Job Description Job Title: ASSISTANT COACH Reports To: HEAD COACH/PRINCIPAL/DIRECTOR OF ATHLETICS/ACTIVITIES Essential Duties and Responsibilities: 1. Has knowledge of existing system and State and NMAA regulations. 2. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Roswell Independent School District Board of Education and is responsible for their implementation. 3. Has knowledge of the existing system, state and league regulations and implements them consistently. 4. Maintains discipline and works to increase morale and cooperate within the school sports program. 5. Recommends to the head coach budgetary items for next year in his area of the program. 6. Monitors equipment rooms and coaches offices and authorizes who may enter. 7. Is accountable to the head coach for all equipment. Collects the cost of any equipment lost or not returned and arranges for issuing and storing of equipment and submits to the head coach an annual inventory and current records concerning this equipment. 8. Examines locker rooms before and after practices and games, checking on general cleanliness of the facility. Responsible for cleanliness and maintenance of the specific equipment. 9. Instills in each player a respect for equipment and school property, its care and proper usage. 10. Assist in the necessary preparation to hold scheduled sports events or practices and adheres to scheduled facility times. 11. Coordinates program with maintenance and school employees. 12. Provides proper safeguards for maintenance and protection of assigned equipment sites. Assists the head coach in scheduling, providing transportation to tournaments and special sporting events. 13. Directs student managers and statisticians on respective games. 14. Provides training rules and any other unique regulation of the sport to each athlete who is considered a participant. 15. Determines student discipline, delineates procedures concerning due process when the enforcement of discipline is necessary. 16. By his presence at all practices, games and while traveling, provides assistance and safeguards for each participant. 17. Instructs team members as to changes in the rules and teaches fundamentals of the sport as outlined by the head coach. 18. Assists the head coach in carrying out his responsibility. 19. Attends all staff meetings and carries out scouting assignments as outlined by the head coach. 20. Works within the basic framework and philosophy of the head coach of that sport. 21. Arrives early enough before practice, contests and meetings to adequately prepare and remains long enough afterwards to help players with problems or to become involved in staff discussions. 22. Never criticizes, admonishes or argues with head coach or any staff member within ears or eyes of players or parents. 23. Strives to improve patterns of performance through in-service meetings and self-motivated research and study. 24. Attends clinics and conventions to improve coaching P a g e | 2 ASSISTANT COACH (CONT’D) Supervisory Responsibilities: Students in his charge. Qualifications: 1. High School diploma or GED. 2. Current NM Coaching licensure including CPR/AED Certification. 3. Valid Driver’s license and Car Insurance. 4. Ability to drive from site to site as needed. Physical Requirements: Sitting, standing, lifting and carrying (up to 40 pounds), climbing stairs, reaching, squatting, kneeling, having full mobility of fingers/hands, and moving light furniture may be required, unless ADA accommodations have been mutually agreed on and does not create an undue hardship upon the district. Job.JobTitle: Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School at Valencia High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Valencia High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Assistant Track Coach Valencia High School maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Valencia High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.
Job.Location: VHS Athletics - Los Lunas, New Mexico
Job.CompanyDescription: Los Lunas Public Schools coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The VMS Track Coach 25-26 role at Los Lunas Public Schools is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the VMS Track Coach 25-26 is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Los Lunas Public Schools, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The VMS Track Coach 25-26 sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Los Lunas Public Schools, the VMS Track Coach 25-26 is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the VMS Track Coach 25-26 at Los Lunas Public Schools is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.
Job.Location: VMS Athletics - Los Lunas, New Mexico
Job.Experience: Coaching experience
Job.SalaryRange: As established by the Los Lunas Schools current Increment Salary Schedule. As per NMAA Season.
Job.CompanyDescription: Los Lunas Public Schools coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
QUALIFICATIONS: Applicants must have a coaching license or a coaching application with results from the NMAA to apply for their coaching license and a complete application on file.
JOB SUMMARY: To prepare athletes for competition. Participation opportunities are offered at the Varsity, Junior Varsity, 'C' Team, 9th-grade, 8th-grade, and 7th-grade levels of competition for many of the sponsored sports.
ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Teaching sports techniques, playing rules, strategies, and playing tactics. Conditioning athletes appropriately for activities requiring endurance, strength, and agility. Supervising and conducting practices and contests safely; supervising locker rooms and buses. Teaching sportsmanship, cooperation, work ethic, and responsibility to one's team. Monitoring athletes' school attendance, grades, and personal conduct. Responding to player injuries with approved first aid techniques. Managing uniforms, equipment, and school facilities in a responsible manner. If Major sports course is offered- Expected to actively participate in offseason program development and implementation, including strength and conditioning, skill development, and team activities. Involvement with the school's major sport athletic class during the academic day is required.
SPECIAL CONDITIONS: Vacancies for coaching positions are developed at each school and forwarded to the Associate Superintendent of Human Resources for posting in schools. Candidates for coaching positions are screened and interviewed by the high school athletic director and/or principal. To apply for a coaching job, candidates submit a letter of interest to the office of Human Resources. The athletic director will review all candidate backgrounds and recommend candidates to be interviewed.
SALARY: Coaching salaries vary depending on the coaching assignment and the level of competition (Freshman, Sophomore, JV, or Varsity). Applicants should list related playing or coaching experiences and any training completed. In addition, candidates should list the sports they feel most comfortable teaching/coaching. (List sports in order of capability.) For further information, interested persons should call the Deming Public Schools Director of Activities and Athletics at 575-546-8126.
Revised January 2026
THE DEMING PUBLIC SCHOOL DISTRICT IS AN EQUAL OPPORTUNITY EMPLOYER AND DOES NOT DISCRIMINATE ON THE BASIS OF RACE, NATIONAL ORIGIN, RELIGION, AGE, SEX, MARITAL STATUS OR HANDICAP IN COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL AND STATE LAWS
Position Type: N/A
Job Requirements Citizenship, residency or work visa required
Contact Information Nelson Diaz, Assistant Principal Athletic Department Phone: 5755468841 Email: nelson.diaz@demingps.org
Job.SalaryRange: Coaching salaries vary depending on the coaching assignment and the level of competition

Job.JobDescription:
Summary: The Coach must demonstrate leadership in player and staff development, integrity, sportsmanship and character development. Qualified candidates should possess strong communication and organizational skills. They must demonstrate professional behavior and exceptional knowledge of the skills and strategies of their sport as it pertains to the policies of New Mexico Activities Association (NMAA). The coach will supervise assistant coaches in conjunction with the school athletic coordinator.
Essential Duties and Responsibilities: * Knowledge in implementing a written team rules which includes a philosophy statement and discusses acceptable player behavior, practice procedures, substance abuse policies and other guidelines that relate to program management. Conduct a pre-season meeting with parents and players to share these policies and procedures. * Have a thorough knowledge of all District and the NMAA Policies and be responsible for their implementation. * Understand and follow the proper administrative line of command and refer to all requests or grievances through proper channels. * Continue professional growth by attending team practices and meeting with the high school head coach. * Conduct oneself as a positive role model. * Assist the high school head coach in implementing all team rules (to vertically align with the high school program). * Turn in team rosters as directed to the school athletic director. * Report all rule violations or suspected violations to the school athletic director. * Consult with the school athletic director, or his/her designee, in matters of purchasing equipment, scheduling, and coaching assignments. * Work to develop a positive athlete-teacher relationship. * Coaches must ensure that all athletes participating in their sport are academically eligible. This includes checking grades before the start of the season and during the season as well. Every student athlete must remain eligible according to NMAA policies. * Implement a sport specific safety plan. This includes a hazards free practice environment. If something needs to be fixed, place a district work order to fix that problem immediately and report it to the Regional Activities Coordinator. * Be responsible for the collection of equipment and have athletic fines resolved by the end of the season. * Prepare travel requests for trips 10 days in advance; rosters and itineraries at least prior to the 24 hours of departure. * Remain at practice or contest until all athletes have left the athletic area. * Inspect the locker room with the visiting coach before and after the contest. * The Head Coach must ride the team bus to and from practices or contests. * Require appropriate behavior on road trips by supervising students at the opponent's school. * Promote and encourage fair play, good sportsmanship, and ethical standards of conduct both on and off the field. * Forewarn all participants that involvement in physical confrontation could result in removal from the game and /or suspension from subsequent games. * Utilize and monitor RankOneSport system. * Maintain a yearly inventory of all new and used equipment. * Comply with all Board of Education policies, administrative regulations, Public Education Department guidelines and local/state/federal laws and the NMAA. * Perform additional job responsibilities as assigned by the supervisor. * Support district and school efforts to keep CCSD safe and secure * Complete and comply with all required trainings annually * Adhere to NM Code of Ethical Responsibility of the Education Profession (NMAC 6.60.9.8) * Other duties as assigned, reasonably related to the scope of the position
Minimum Qualifications: * Valid NM Athletic Coaching License * Valid New Mexico Teaching License preferred * All Athletic Coaches in K-8 settings MUST be at least 18 years of age, and ALL Athletic Coaches in 9-12 settings MUST be at least 21 years of age.
Knowledge, Skills and Abilities: * Knowledge of Dine language, culture, and history preferred * Good communication skills and customer service skill * Previous high school coaching experience preferred * Knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport * Current CPR and first aid certification
Physical/Job Requirements: Standing, sitting, walking, lifting, carrying up to 50 pounds, climbing, bending, reaching, kneeling, driving a vehicle, traveling long distances, writing, typing, word processing, reading, researching information, and effective communication skills.
Job.Experience: Valid NM Athletic Coaching License, Previous high school coaching experience preferred
Job.CompanyDescription: Central Consolidated Sch. Dist. coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Wappingers Central School District is seeking coaching applicants for a variety of openings for the 2025-26 school year.
Salary is based on the WCT Contractual coaching rates.
All applicants must have a valid fingerprint report from NYS, current Sports First Aid & CPR certifications and a current NYS sport-specific coaching license.
To apply upload your resume, a cover letter and 3 letters of recommendation (written and dated within the past 18 months by a non-WCSD employee and signed by the author. Blank or computer-generated signatures are not acceptable).
Job Qualifications Fingerprint clearance through NYS TEACH Valid NYS Coaching License Application Procedure NYSED Fingerprint Clearance is required.

The Head JV Girls Golf Coach role at Jay Schwanke emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Head JV Girls Golf Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Jay Schwanke, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Head JV Girls Golf Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Jay Schwanke at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Head JV Girls Golf Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Head JV Girls Golf Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Head JV Girls Golf Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Jay Schwanke.

The Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach position at John Bernans is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At John Bernans, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach role at John Bernans is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.
Job.Experience: depending on years of credited experience

Job.JobDescription:
The Head 8th Grade Baseball Coach position at John Bernans provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Head 8th Grade Baseball Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At John Bernans, the Head 8th Grade Baseball Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Head 8th Grade Baseball Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Head 8th Grade Baseball Coach at John Bernans is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

The Head JV Softball Coach at Jay Schwanke is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Head JV Softball Coach manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Jay Schwanke, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Head JV Softball Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Head JV Softball Coach follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Head JV Softball Coach at Jay Schwanke allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

The Head JV Girls Golf Coach at Jerome High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Head JV Girls Golf Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Jerome High School, the Head JV Girls Golf Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Head JV Girls Golf Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Jerome High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Head JV Girls Golf Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobTitle: Head Boys Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Boys Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season at Eversole Run Middle School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Head Boys Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Eversole Run Middle School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Head Boys Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Head Boys Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Head Boys Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Eversole Run Middle School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.
Job.Experience: Previous coaching experience is preferred, but not required

Job.JobTitle: Head Girls Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Girls Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season position at Eversole Run Middle School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Head Girls Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Eversole Run Middle School, the Head Girls Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Head Girls Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Head Girls Lacrosse Coach Spring 2026 Season at Eversole Run Middle School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobDescription:
The Head Softball Coach role at Grizzell Middle School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Head Softball Coach is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Grizzell Middle School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Head Softball Coach sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Grizzell Middle School, the Head Softball Coach is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Head Softball Coach at Grizzell Middle School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

The Assistant Softball Coach position at Jay Ohlinger is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Assistant Softball Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Assistant Softball Coach at Jay Ohlinger sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Jay Ohlinger, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Assistant Softball Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Assistant Softball Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Assistant Softball Coach position at Jay Ohlinger is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The Assistant Track Coach (Throws) at Trey Jones is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Assistant Track Coach (Throws) are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Trey Jones use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Assistant Track Coach (Throws) recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Assistant Track Coach (Throws) collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Assistant Track Coach (Throws) maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Trey Jones. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Coaching - HS Varsity Asst. Softball Coach
Job.JobDescription:
Job Responsibilities:
* Assist the Varsity Head Coach with the Girls Softball Program. * Assist with developing and training student-athletes to participate in play softball. * Assist with the development and execution of an effective training program. * Monitor, motivate, supervise, and mentor student-athletes on and off the Field. * Ensure the safety and well-being of student-athletes. * Instruct and guide student-athletes in fundamental skills, strategies, and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. * Instruct and guide student-athletes to lead them to the formulation and enhancement of moral values, pride of accomplishment, acceptable social behavior, self-discipline, and self-confidence. * Foster teamwork, sportsmanship, and skills development. * Schedule a full season of contests including State-Tournament Games. * Work cooperatively and in a timely manner, with School Athletic Office and CPS District Athletics Department, in regard to all requests for information that might be periodically required. * Check the status of academic eligibility for all prospective student-athletes. * Follow District Athletic Department Policy as outlined in Coaches Handbook and meet all criteria as outlined in job description. * Meet all requirements set forth by the State Board of Education, CPS, the Ohio High School Athletic Association (OHSAA), and The Ohio Department of Education (ODE) relative to the mandated Coaches Tool Chest (CTC) and ODE Pupil Activity Permit (PAP). * Recognize the need to be aware of and implement all applicable administrative policies set forth by the Board of Education, Superintendents of Schools, School Principals, Conference Leagues, OHSAA. * Provide all applicable in-season training rules as well as any that may apply to out-of-season conduct to team members in writing prior to the start of the season. Follow appropriate due process procedures when violations occur. * Model the behavior expected of our student-athletes including timeliness to games and practices, being positive and enthusiastic, being respectful, and practicing constructive criticism while upholding the disciplines of the program. * Be appropriately dressed at all times. * Maintain suitable sideline conduct, including the use of appropriate language, at all times. * Accept and profit from constructive criticism and suggestions for improving coaching performance. * Participate in clinics and other available programs to improve coaching performance. * Participate in School Events (i.e., Awards Night Programs, Pep Assemblies, Athletic Boosters Meetings, etc.). * Show physical vitality for the sport as well as use of good judgement and decision-making. * Be competent in techniques of the sport so that student-athletes respond positively to directions given. * Demonstrate the ability to adapt properly to changing game situations. * Be well-versed and knowledgeable in matters pertaining to the sport and look at ways to constantly improve knowledge and coaching techniques. * Be innovative in using new coaching techniques and ideas in addition to already proven methods of coaching. * Ensure that team is well-prepared for opponents. * Maintain accurate inventory of equipment and supplies.
Skills/Essential Functions:
* Fundraising experience. * Previous experience coaching softball required. * Have a passion and dedication to motivate and inspire student-athletes. * Ability to serve as a positive role model. * Demonstrated knowledge of skills associated with this sport. * Ability to work effectively in a multicultural environment.
Training/Certifications:
* Ohio Secondary Teaching Certificate preferred. * Successful participation in a similar activity in high school and/or college. * Provide a satisfactory result on a County Police Records Check, State BCII Check, and FBI Fingerprint Background Check. * Possess an Ohio Department of Education (ODE) Pupils Activity Permit (PAP). * Provide proof of completion of Coaches Tool Chest (CTC) Training/Certification
Contract Provisions: Type of Contract: Supplemental Annual Limited Salary: Per Schedule E of current C.F.T. Labor Agreement
Reports To: Principal
Application Procedure: Apply Online
Selection Procedure: Interview
Position Type: Part-Time
Job.Location: James N Gamble Montessori HS - CINCINNATI, Ohio
Job.SalaryRange: Per Schedule E of current C.F.T. Labor Agreement
Job.CompanyDescription: Cincinnati City School District coaching jobs
