HS Asst Girls Volleyball Coach Position Type: Athletics/Activities/Coaching Date Posted: 1/6/2026 Location: Perrysburg High School Date Available: 2026-27 School year
Opening for a High School Assistant Girls Volleyball Coach for Fall 2026-27 season.
Applicant must have or obtain a current Pupil Activity Permit and CPR.
If you have questions, please contact Chuck Jaco at 419-874-3181 X5194.
Reports To: High School Athletic Director
Qualifications: 1. Valid driver's license 2. State of Ohio Teaching License (preferred, not required). 3. Coaching and administrative abilities. 4. Required to maintain a valid CPR card, BCI and certification from the Ohio Department of Education through the Pupil Activity Validation Program. Proof of both certificates must be on file with the Athletic Director prior to coaching. 5. Ability to relate to, communicate with and inspire young athletes. 6. Knowledge of prevention and care of athletic injuries. 7. Organizational skills/resources to enhance the program. 8. Skill in oral presentations. 9. Ability to get along with other coaches. 10. Desire to invest time during season. 11. Knowledge of the sport with emphasis on fundamentals. 12. Knowledge of training and conditioning techniques. 13. Ability to diagnose player deficiencies and prescribe corrective activities. 14. Ability to make minor repairs on equipment. 15. Conscientious and assumes responsibility for own work. 16. Good health, high moral character and good attendance record. 17. Demonstrate enthusiasm and a sincere desire to aid all students.
General Description: To prepare a sport team for interscholastic competition.
Essential Functions: 1. Encourage students to participate in the program. 2. Account for the condition, inventory, distribution and procurement of all equipment. 3. Account for the procurement and distribution of all medical supplies and equipment. 4. Account for assignment of lockers and the condition of the locker room. 5. Schedule, record and assist as needed with physical examinations for all players. 6. Account for the collection of all fees. 7. Instruct and assist players in the prevention and care of injuries. 8. Accountable for all players meeting necessary requirements pertaining to insurance, physical cards, eligibility forms and athletic waivers. 9. Attend rules interpretation meetings. 10. Assist in the preparation of facilities for all games and practice sessions. 11. Schedule, plan and conduct all practice sessions and scrimmages. 12. Accountable for player behavior during practice sessions, meetings, locker room activities, bus trips and other activities under the support of the program. 13. Schedule and conduct meetings to discuss forthcoming opponents. 14. Support the athletic program as a whole. 15. Delegate specific duties, supervise implementation and, at season's end, analyze staff effectiveness and evaluate all assistant coaches. 16. Contribute to public relations by providing information to newspapers, radios and television stations, school newspapers and other school publications. 17. Correspond with college and university personnel to assist high school players in acquiring athletic scholarships. 18. Communicate with classroom teachers to determine the achievement level of each player. 19. Maintain a record of team statistics and requirements for lettering or certificates of award. 20. Participate in Awards Program by distributing awards to the players. 21. Instruct and supervise managers and statisticians in game and practice preparation. 22. Attend and participate in athletic booster club meetings. 23. Evaluate players after each game and at the end of the season through an exit interview. 24. Develop and enforce training rules. 25. Organize filming of games; present and discuss game films from previous contests; review and evaluate all game films. 26. Follow and enforce Perrysburg High School Co-Curricular Code of Conduct.
Other Duties and Responsibilities: 1. Serve as a role model for students in how to conduct themselves as citizens and as responsible, intelligent human beings. 2. Help instill in students the belief in and practice of sportsmanship, ethics and integrity, as it pertains to the Board of Education Adopted Policy 2431B – Sportsmanship Expectations. 3. Conduct other duties related to the coach’s duties as assigned by the Athletic Director and/or Principal.

Job.JobTitle: LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position ***2026-2027
Job.JobDescription:
The LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 role at Lebanon Junior High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Lebanon Junior High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Lebanon Junior High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 at Lebanon Junior High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

The Louisville Leopards are a D-III Girls Volleyball program. We are looking for a candidate that has had previous experience working at the varsity level, in an inter-scholastic coaching environment. The candidate should be familiar with local and state regulations and eligibility standards. Candidates must demonstrate the ability to develop a strong, cohesive program and be able to cultivate a culture focused on academics, athletic excellence and moral character. Qualified candidates shall possess effective communication skills, including the ability to establish rapport with parents, student athletes, administration, faculty and staff. They should also possess effective organizational skills, be committed to being a positive role model on and off the court, and have the knowledge to grow an overall successful volleyball program from youth to varsity level. Candidates should hold or be willing to obtain all necessary certifications as required by the state and district.

JH Track Assistant - Level E $2644-$3039
Must Obtain the Following Credentials Favorable BCI Background Check Favorable FBI Background Check CPR First Aid for Coaches/Sports Safety Training Fundamentals of Coaching Certification Concussion Training Sudden Cardiac Arrest Training Pupil Validation Permit from ODE
Application must be completed to be considered.
QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Has the ability to organize and supervise a total sports program. 2. Has previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. (Major sports) 3. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 4. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions.
REPORTS TO: The athletic director, who provides overall objectives and final evaluation in conjunction with the high school principals
SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal.
JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self discipline, self confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc.
GENERAL: 1. The success of athletic programs has a strong influence on the community's image of the entire system. The public exposure is a considerable responsibility and community/parent pressure for winning performance is taxing, but must not override the objectives of good sportsmanship and good mental health. 2. The position includes other unusual aspect such as extended time, risk injury factor and due process predicaments. 3. It is the express intent of this job description to give sufficient guidance to function in cases not specifically covered, it shall be assumed that a coach shall exercise common sense and good judgment.
DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: 1. Has a thorough knowledge of all the athletic policies approved by the Schools' Board of Education and is responsible for their implementation by the entire staff of the sports program. 2. Has knowledge of existing system, state and league regulations; implements same consistently and interprets them for staff. 3. Understands the proper administrative line of command and refers all requests or grievances through proper channels. Is aware of all public/staff/departmental meetings that require attendance.
STAFF RESPONSIBILITIES: 4. Established the fundamental philosophy, skills and techniques to be taught by staff. Designs conferences, clinics and staff meetings to insure staff awareness of overall program. 5. Trains and informs staff, encourages professional growth by encouraging clinic attendance according to local clinic policy. 6. Delegates specific duties, supervises implementation and, at season's end, analyzes staff effectiveness and evaluates all assistants. 7. Maintains discipline, adjusts grievances and works to increase morale and cooperation. 8. Performs such other duties which may be assigned by the athletic director/principal.
ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES: 9. Assists the athletic director in scheduling, providing transportation and requirements for tournament and special sport events. 10. Assists in the necessary preparation to hold scheduled sport events or practices and adheres to scheduled facility times. Coordinates program with maintenance and school employees. 11. Provides documentation to fulfill state and system requirements concerning physical examinations, parental consent and eligibility. 12. Provides proper safeguards for maintenance and protection of assigned equipment sites. 13. Advises the athletic director and recommends policy, method or procedural changes.
STUDENT RESPONSIBILITIES: 14. Serves as a mentor to each athlete to promote the development and demonstration in student athletes the character traits of trustworthiness, respect, responsibility, fairness, caring, and citizenship. 15. Gives constant attention to a student athlete's grades and conduct. 16. By his/her presence at all practices games and while traveling, provides assistance, guidance and safeguards for each participant. 17. Provides training rules and any other unique regulations of the sport to each athlete who is considered a participant. 18. Initiates programs and policies concerning injuries, medical attention and emergencies. 19. Completes paperwork on all disabling athletic injuries on proper forms and submits to athletic office within 24 hours. 20. Directs student managers, assistants and statisticians. 21. Determines discipline, delineates procedures concerning due process when the enforcement of discipline is necessary and contracts parents when a student is dropped or becomes ineligible. 22. Assists athletes in their college or advanced educational selection.
FINANCE AND EQUIPMENT: 23. Participates in the budgeting function with the athletic director by establishing requirements for the next season. Recommends equipment guidelines as to type, style, color or technical specifications. Is responsible for operating within budget appropriations. 24. Is accountable for all equipment and collects the cost of any equipment lost or not returned. Arranges for issuing, storing and reconditioning of equipment and submits annual inventory and current records concerning same. 25. Properly marks and identifies all equipment before issuing or storing. 26. Monitors equipment rooms and coaches' offices, authorizes who may enter, issue or requisition equipment. 27. Permits the athletes to only be in authorized areas of the building at the appropriate times. 28. Examines locker rooms before and after practices and games, checking on general cleanliness of the facility. Responsible for cleanliness and maintenance of specific sport equipment. 29. Secures all doors, lights, windows and locks before leaving building if custodians are not on duty. 30. Instills in each player a respect for equipment and school property, its care and proper use.
PUBLIC RELATIONS: 31. Organizes parents, coaches, players and guests for preseason meetings. 32. Promotes the sport within the school through recruiting athletes who are not in another sports program and promotes the sport outside the school through news media, little league programs, or in any other feasible manner. 33. Responsible for the quality, effectiveness and validity of any oral or written release to local media. 34. Responsible for maintaining good public relations with news media, booster club, parents, officials, volunteers and fans. 35. Presents information to news media concerning schedules, tournaments and results.

The Head Baseball Coach at MSE/MSS/MSW (combined) is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Head Baseball Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at MSE/MSS/MSW (combined) reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Head Baseball Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Head Baseball Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Head Baseball Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at MSE/MSS/MSW (combined). Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: Track - Assistant Coach, South Salem High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Track - Assistant Coach, South Salem High School at SOUTH SALEM HIGH SCHOOL is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Track - Assistant Coach, South Salem High School are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at SOUTH SALEM HIGH SCHOOL use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Track - Assistant Coach, South Salem High School recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Track - Assistant Coach, South Salem High School collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Track - Assistant Coach, South Salem High School maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at SOUTH SALEM HIGH SCHOOL. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Softball - Assistant Coach, North Salem High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Softball - Assistant Coach, North Salem High School at NORTH SALEM HIGH SCHOOL is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Softball - Assistant Coach, North Salem High School is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At NORTH SALEM HIGH SCHOOL, the Softball - Assistant Coach, North Salem High School helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Softball - Assistant Coach, North Salem High School may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents NORTH SALEM HIGH SCHOOL well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Softball - Assistant Coach, North Salem High School follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobTitle: Softball - Assistant Coach, Sprague High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Softball - Assistant Coach, Sprague High School role at Sprague High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Softball - Assistant Coach, Sprague High School is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Sprague High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Softball - Assistant Coach, Sprague High School sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Sprague High School, the Softball - Assistant Coach, Sprague High School is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Softball - Assistant Coach, Sprague High School at Sprague High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: Head Boys Varsity Soccer Coach | Hillsboro High School
Job.JobDescription:
E1016SY2526 | Head Boys Varsity Soccer Coach | Hillsboro High School
GENERAL DUTIES: Support the Hillsboro School District athletic objective, policy of interscholastic athletics, and Hillsboro School District Athletic Code. The District believes that extra-curricular activities are an integral part of school life. All students, regardless of their ability, should take part if possible to be able to grow physically, intellectually, and socially through participation. Coaches organize and conduct the athletic programs to meet the needs of the school district and their participants.
ESSENTIAL REQUIREMENTS: * Experience in and/or knowledge of the sport, coaching techniques, and student supervision. * Ability and willingness to effectively communicate in verbal and written modes with student/athletes, parents, assistant coaches, and other school staff. * Ability and willingness to perform coaching responsibilities in accordance with school and District procedures and policies. * Must have current CPR/First Aid certification. * Must have current Concussion Management and other trainings required by the OSAA. * Maintain integrity of confidential information relating to students, staff, or District patrons. * The ability to work harmoniously with others and collaborate solutions to concerns. * Successfully pass background check.

3 positions available Season dates: 3/2/2026-5/1/2026
Medford School District 549C
JOB TITLE: Assistant Athletic Coach - Middle School CLASSIFICATION: Extra Duty SUPERVISOR: Building Principal CONTRACT: Athletic Season
GENERAL STATEMENT OF RESPONSIBILITIES The Assistant Coach will work to carry out the aims and objectives of the sport program as outlined by the Head Coach. The Assistant Coach is to instruct athletes in individual and team fundamentals, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. It is the intent of this job description to give sufficient guidance to function. In case not specifically covered, it shall be assumed that a coach shall exercise common sense and good judgment. The Assistant Coach supervises athletes and teams assigned to him/her and assumes supervising control over all athletes in program when such control is needed. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES 1. Has a thorough knowledge of all the Athletic Policies endorsed by the Medford School District Board of Education and is responsible for its compliance. 2. Has knowledge of Southern Oregon Junior High Athletic Conference rules and regulations implements those same consistently and is responsible for compliance. 3. Understands the proper administrative line of command and refers all requests or grievances through proper channels. 4. Works to increase morale and cooperation within the school's entire athletic program. 5. Knows effective safety procedures in their sport, plans and implements a program of instruction in safe practices. ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES 1. Assists the Head Coach in scheduling and making travel arrangements when asked. 2. Works with the Head Coach to prepare and adhere to scheduled facility times. 3. Assists the Head Coach in matters related to compliance with district requirements concerning physical examinations, parental consent forms, insurance waivers, and eligibility. 4. Assists the Head Coach in providing proper safeguards for maintenance and protection of assigned equipment and facilities and teaching the planned safety program. STUDENT RESPONSIBILITIES 1. Provides training rules and any other unique regulations of the sport to each athlete who is considered a participant. 2. Supervises the athletes before, during, and after practices, contests, or while traveling, and provides by his/her presence proper guidance and safeguards for each participant. 3. Follows program, implemented by the Head Coach, related to injuries, medical attention, and emergencies. Works cooperatively with the athletic trainer in matters of injury,prevention, and the care and rehabilitation of athletic injuries. 4. Directs student managers, assistants and statisticians on respective teams. 5. Determines discipline, in accordance with State, district, and school guidelines, policies and procedures. Teaches athletes rules and procedures concerning due process when the enforcement of discipline is necessary. Contacts parents when a student is dropped or becomes ineligible for team rule infractions. EQUIPMENT AND FACILITIES 1. Is accountable to the Head Coach for all equipment and assists in identifying lost or stolen equipment, and issuing fine and hold notices to the Office. 2. Monitors equipment rooms and coaches office and authorizes who may enter. 3. Examines locker rooms before and after practices and games, checking on general cleanliness of the facility. 4. Secures all doors, lights, windows, and locks before leaving building if custodians are not on duty. 5. Instills in each player a respect for equipment and school property, its care and proper use. PROGRAM RESPONSIBILITIES 1. Assists the Head Coach in carrying out his/her responsibilities. 2. Instructs team members as to changes in the rules and teaches fundamentals of the sport as outlined by the Head Coach. 3. Works within the basic framework and philosophy of the Head Coach of that sport. 4. Attends all staff meetings as required by the Head Coach. 5. Arrives early enough before practice and contests to adequately prepare and remains long enough afterwards to help players with problems or to become involved with staff discussions. 6. Never criticizes, admonishes, or argues with the Head Coach or any staff member within ears or eyes of players, parents, or fans. 7. Strives to improve skills by attending clinics and using resources made available by the Head Coach. 8. Attends most of the contests, when possible, of other teams in the program. 9. Performs other such duties that are consistent with the nature of the position and that may be requested by the Head Coach. QUALIFICATIONS: To perform this position successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skill, and/or ability required. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. MINIMUM SKILLS AND ABILITIES: Knowledge: 1. Of rules and regulations of the sport to which assigned. 2. Of fundamentals, techniques, and strategies of the sport to which assigned. 3. Of safety factors involved in the sport assigned. 4. Of physical ability and limitations of the level he/she is teaching. 5. Of the Medford School District Athletic Policies and OSAA Rules and Regulations. Skills: 1. Must possess the ability to communicate effectively with people. 2. Must be able to demonstrate basic skills of sport to which assigned. 3. Must have the ability to organize, supervise, and evaluate the total sport program. Attitudes: 1. Must be positive. 2. Should be enthusiastic. 3. Should possess a willingness to cooperate and to adjust to various situations. Experience: 1. Previous coaching experience of sport to which assigned is preferred. 2. Previous experience as participant of sport to which assigned preferred. 3. Previous teaching experience preferred. Education: 1. Valid Oregon teacher certification is preferred. 2. College training in coaching desirable. PHYSICAL DEMANDS AND WORKING CONDITIONS: The physical demands described below are representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform the essential functions of this position. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.

Job.JobTitle: Head Track Coach - Wilsonville Middle School
Job.JobDescription:
Head Track Coach - Wilsonville Middle School Experienced and quality coach in various aspects of track. One who has a program-wide approach and establishes positive rapport with staff and student-athletes.
Responsible for running daily practices, supervising assistant coaches, and planning and organizing two home track meets.
Community and District Information: The West Linn-Wilsonville School District is nestled within two thriving cities, West Linn and Wilsonville, within the rural area of Clackamas County. Both communities have a strong legacy of support for their schools, music and arts endeavors, and the overall well-being of their patrons. The school district and surrounding communities have experienced steady, constant growth over the past three decades. The estimated student population of the District as of December 2024 is 8,900.
It is the policy of the West Linn-Wilsonville Board of Education and School District (WLWV) that no discrimination or harassment on the grounds of race, color, national origin, religion, sex, sexual orientation, age, marital status, veterans’ status, genetic information, or disability shall occur if the employee with or without reasonable accommodation, is able to perform the essential functions of the position. These protections apply to students, employees, and other members of the public. West Linn-Wilsonville School District is committed to equal access and equal opportunity in all activities/services, educational programs, and employment. Persons having questions regarding equal opportunity and nondiscrimination should contact the Director of Human Resources at the West Linn-Wilsonville School District, 503-673-7095.

Position Overview: The role of the Assistant Coach is to support the Head Coach and be responsible for coaching, character development and providing direction to student athletes so that they might achieve a high level of skill as well as an appreciation for discipline, sportsmanship and teamwork. Greater Albany Public Schools believes that our Coaches must assume a major role in fostering cooperation and positive teamwork, exhibiting outstanding sportsmanship and fan involvement at games and special events and most importantly, assume a major role in the development of our youth as future leaders. This job requires you to interact thoughtfully and respectfully with student athletes, fellow coaches, staff, parents and community. Positive communication strategies, organizational skills and safety awareness are key requirements. Please Note: This is a brief description/summary of the position. Please see attached to view the full job description. Greater Albany Public Schools (GAPS) mission is "Building Bridges to Lifelong Learning and Brighter Futures." We strive to realize that mission for every child and adult, every day. Because of our commitment to that mission, GAPS is a great place to work and live. An easy drive to Eugene, Corvallis, and Salem, and less than ninety minutes from Portland, Albany offers a small town quality feel near urban amenities, magnificent natural resources, and the state's two largest public universities (University of Oregon and Oregon State University). Residents enjoy easy access to the pacific coastline beaches, hiking and biking trails along the coastal mountain range, snowboard and skiing opportunities in the mountains to our east, and in its backyard the natural splendor of the Willamette Valley with its roving hills and wineries.

Job.JobTitle: Head Boys Tennis Coach - Benson HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics
Job.JobDescription:
Posting Timeline This job is open until filled. Applications will be reviewed as received. Portland Public Schools reserves the right to make a hiring decision at any point during the posting period.
Position Details DISTRICT MISSION: At PPS, our goal is that by the end of elementary, middle and high school every student by name is meeting or exceeding academic standards and is fully prepared to make productive life decisions. DISTRICT PROFILE: To obtain more information about our district, schools, learning environment and programs, please go to https://www.pps.net/Domain/265. Key points of the job description for a Varsity Head Coach: High ethical and professional standards. Direct a successful grade 9-12 program and oversee all facets of an entire community youth program. 3 years of High School coaching experience Be a role model for high school student-athletes. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports by encouraging student-athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program. Lead student-athletes in the support of other Portland Public Schools athletics and activities.
The Head Coach will be responsible for the following: Manage all aspects of the high school program including training, practice schedules and routines. Hire and oversee a staff of assistant coaches Provide regular communication with parents/families Regularly track the academic progress of all student-athletes in the program and facilitate necessary supports to ensure their academic eligibility. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports and encourage athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program for athletics.
All new hired coaches will need to complete the following prior to employment: NFHS/ASEP Certification First Aid Card (CPR and AED trained) District Fingerprinting/Criminal check Completion of OSAA Concussion Test Completion of ODE Steroid Test Completion of OSAA Heat Test *Head Up Football *Cheer and Dance/Drill Spirit Safety Training Completion of Portland Public School District paperwork and trainings.
Applicant will be asked to apply online at our website and include the following: A cover letter detailing your experience. A current resume. A minimum of three letters of recommendation/reference.
All PPS job offers are contingent on the satisfactory completion of a background check, including fingerprinting and criminal records.
Salary Range - $6100.00 to $10,000.00
* There is no compensation for summer and out of season workouts.
Portland Public Schools (PPS) is seeking talented people from diverse backgrounds and experiences to lead change and inspire PPS students. At PPS, every employee, despite having different roles, is an educator. We hope to attract talented educators who model the core PPS Educator Essentials. With the District’s focus on eliminating systemic racism and its adverse impact on student learning, we seek to hire individuals who bring to our district a deep commitment to racial equity and social justice.
The District is committed to equal opportunity and nondiscrimination in all its educational and employment activities. The District prohibits discrimination based on perceived or actual race; national or ethnic origin; color; sex; religion; age; sexual orientation; gender expression or identity; pregnancy; marital status; veteran’s status; familial status; economic status or source of income; mental or physical disability or perceived disability; or military service.

Job.Experience: 3 years

Job.JobTitle: .5 FTE Assistant Track Coach - Caldera High School - Regular
Job.JobDescription:
Bend-La Pine Schools is committed to the principle of equity. Equity supersedes the notion of equality, where all are treated the same. Pursuing equity requires the removal of barriers and the promotion of inclusive practices so that all students fully benefit. The principle of equity will inform all BLS policies, regulations, programs, operations, practices, and resource allocations.
Studies have shown that some individuals (women and people of color, for example) are less likely to apply for jobs unless they believe they meet every single qualification in a job description. Our goal is to find the best candidate for the position, and we acknowledge that that candidate may be an individual from a less traditional background. We encourage you to apply, even if you don’t believe you meet every one of our qualifications described. If you are unsure whether you meet the qualifications of a position, or how this would be determined, please feel free to contact Human Resources to discuss your application.
As you prepare to submit your application for employment, please note that all consideration of experience for the position and initial salary placements will be based upon the information you submit with your original application. Resumes must be detailed and verifiable for successful experience credit, any information provided to Bend-La Pine Schools at a later date will not be the basis for adjustments in salary placement.
Bend La Pine Schools Assistant Coaching Details
General Job Qualifications and Key Responsibilities of the Assistant Coach:
Hold high ethical and professional standards. Be an appropriate role model for high school student-athletes. Hold high expectations and accountability both behaviorally and academically for all student-athletes and coaching staff. Ability to develop, articulate, and implement a vision for your individual discipline. Ability to work in a cooperative and harmonious manner in an educationally based, school-wide athletic program. Experience in the specific discipline at high school level preferred. Be relationship/process oriented. Be involved in fundraising for the program. Communicate effectively with head coach and athletic director. Be an advocate for the multi-sport athlete. Be a supporter of the head coach and the direction they are taking the program. Other duties as assigned by Head Coach & Athletic Director.
Newly hired coaches will be required to complete or show proof of the following certifications prior to employment: 1. NFHS Fundamentals of Coaching (one-time requirement, previous completion will be recognized) 2. Concussion in Sports (yearly) 3. Heat Illness Prevention (every 4 years) District Background check 4. Appearance and Performance Enhancing Drugs and Substances Training (every 4 years) 5. Heads up certification (Yearly) (Football only) 6. First Aid/CPR/AED (every 2 years) (paid coaches only) 7. Bend La Pine Safe Schools Trainings (Yearly)
Requirements Please Provide: Resume Cover Letter
Note: The system will not take uploads from current employees, so please email supporting documents to hr-recruitment@bend.k12.or.us
Additional Information School Year/Contract 2025/26 – Contract Days: 57 Posting End Date Feb 15, 2026 Benefit Status This position is not Benefited

Job.JobDescription:
The Anticipated Volleyball Junior High Coach-Girls position at Cedar Cliff High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Anticipated Volleyball Junior High Coach-Girls prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Cedar Cliff High School, the Anticipated Volleyball Junior High Coach-Girls works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Anticipated Volleyball Junior High Coach-Girls encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Anticipated Volleyball Junior High Coach-Girls at Cedar Cliff High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Spring Track Coach at Harriton High School - Rosemont is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Spring Track Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Harriton High School - Rosemont, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant Spring Track Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant Spring Track Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Harriton High School - Rosemont operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Harriton High School - Rosemont with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Assistant Spring Track Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant Spring Track Coach role at Harriton High School - Rosemont.

Job.JobTitle: Boys and Girls Assistant Track and Field Coach - Pole Vault
Job.JobDescription:
The Boys and Girls Assistant Track and Field Coach - Pole Vault position at Lower Merion High School - Ardmore is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Boys and Girls Assistant Track and Field Coach - Pole Vault is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Lower Merion High School - Ardmore, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Boys and Girls Assistant Track and Field Coach - Pole Vault encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Boys and Girls Assistant Track and Field Coach - Pole Vault also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Boys and Girls Assistant Track and Field Coach - Pole Vault role at Lower Merion High School - Ardmore is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobDescription: The High School Girls Tennis Assistant Coach plays a vital role in the development of student-athletes by fostering teamwork, discipline, and a strong work ethic. Working in collaboration with the head coach, the assistant coach supports the overall vision of the tennis program by focusing on skill development, match strategy, and individual player growth. Responsibilities include assisting with practice planning, teaching fundamental tennis techniques, preparing athletes for competition, and promoting sportsmanship and respect on and off the court. The assistant coach helps create a positive, inclusive team environment that emphasizes effort, accountability, and character, supporting student-athletes as they build confidence, leadership skills, and a lifelong appreciation for the game of tennis. Primary Duties and Responsibilities: Function within the philosophy and objectives developed by the District's interscholastic athletic programs as well as within guidelines available in the Co-Curricular Manual and in building manuals. Enhance coaching skills through subscription to professional journals, membership in professional associations and attendance at clinics. Administer emergency treatment of injuries in the absence of a trainer, physician or other person more qualified than him/herself. Project a positive model for student-athletes, the general student body, and the community at large through appearance, positive attitude, enthusiastic personality, emotional maturity, self-control, leadership, planning, preparation, and good sportsmanship. Teach each athlete skills necessary for the appropriate position in the sport, using proven and up-to date coaching techniques. Maintain total loyalty, support of, and communication with the head coach and program while assisting the former in physical, mental and skills preparation of the student-athletes. Apply disciplinary procedures fairly and in concert with those of the head coach, school and District. Effectively utilize practice time allotted by the head coach in the prescribed manner to further individual and team performance. Complete additional duties as assigned by the Athletic Director or assigned principal. Where: Central York High School 601 Mundis Mill Road York, PA 17406 Qualifications: * Combination of education and experience necessary to perform the tasks outlined in this job description * Must have ( or willing ot obtain) current PA Criminal, PA Child Abuse and FBI Fingerprint History Background Clearances.

Job.JobTitle: Coach - Baseball, Assistant Coach (Spring) - High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - Baseball, Assistant Coach (Spring) - High School role at High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Coach - Baseball, Assistant Coach (Spring) - High School is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Coach - Baseball, Assistant Coach (Spring) - High School listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Coach - Baseball, Assistant Coach (Spring) - High School encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Coach - Baseball, Assistant Coach (Spring) - High School follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Coach - Baseball, Assistant Coach (Spring) - High School at High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.
Job.SalaryRange: Based on experience in accordance with the Profesional Collective Bargaining Agreement.

Job.JobDescription:
The Middle School Girls Lacrosse Coach at Avon Grove Middle School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Middle School Girls Lacrosse Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Avon Grove Middle School, the Middle School Girls Lacrosse Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Middle School Girls Lacrosse Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Avon Grove Middle School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Middle School Girls Lacrosse Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobDescription: EQUAL OPPORTUNITY EMPLOYER 1.20.26 Cheltenham School District announces the following extra duty-extra pay position is available for the 2026-2027 school-year, at Cheltenham High School: Football - Head Coach Reports to: Athletic Director Position Summary The Head Football Coach is responsible for leading a highly competitive and well-rounded interscholastic football program in accordance with PIAA regulations, district policies, and education-based athletics principles. The coach will provide strong leadership, promote academic achievement, foster character development, and ensure a safe positive experience for all student athletes while building a sustainable year-round program. Minimum Qualifications High school diploma required; bachelor's degree preferred. Prior head coaching experience at the high school varsity level is required Current clearances as required by state and district policy CPR, AED and First Aid certification Demonstrated knowledge of football fundamentals, rules and safety protocols Familiarity with NCAA eligibility guidelines and the college recruitment process Strong organizational communication and leadership skills Ability to work effectively with students, parents/guardians, staff, and administration Commitment to educational based athletics and year round student athlete development. All applicants: Must complete the on-line application to be considered for this position, which is located under Employment Opportunities at www.cheltenham.org. External candidates: If hired, you will be required to provide Acts 34, 114, and 151 clearances and other mandatory employment forms. Position vacancies will remain posted until filled.

The Football (Head Coach) 2026 at Cheltenham High School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Football (Head Coach) 2026 manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Cheltenham High School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Football (Head Coach) 2026 demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Football (Head Coach) 2026 follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Football (Head Coach) 2026 at Cheltenham High School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobDescription:
PRIMARY PURPOSE: To ensure the safety of all visitors to the aquatic facility and maintain orderliness.
DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: 1. Maintains active surveillance of the pool area 2. Monitoring designated areas to recognize signs of danger 3. Responds to emergency situations immediately in accordance with district policies, procedures; completes related reports as required 4. Performs all lifeguard duties, including ability to lift people out of pool, perform CPR/first aid, scan pool to ensure safety of participants 5. Explaining and enforcing rules, regulations, and policies to ensure the safety of patrons as requested by supervising teacher 6. Warn swimmers regarding unsafe situations 7. Participation of in-service training as required by the school and district 8. Asses situations swiftly and make judicious decisions regarding the safety of swimmers
REQUIREMENTS: 1. Must be 18 years of age or older 2. Completion of American Red Cross lifeguard training 3. First Aid and CPR/Pro certification 4. Proficient communication skills, both verbal and written 5. Proficient in interacting with people of various ages from diverse backgrounds 6. Available to work different shifts 7. Ability to maintain certification level physical and mental readiness
ADDITIONAL SKILLS, KNOWLEDGE, AND ATTITUDE: 1. Ability to communicate effectively 2. Ability to exercise sound judgment
PHYSICAL DEMANDS: 1. Ability to reach above and below the waist 2. Ability to use fingers to pick up, feel, and grasp objects 3. Physically perform all skills required of a lifeguard 4. Hear noises and distress signals in the aquatic environment, including in the water and anywhere around the zone of responsibility 5. Ability to lift and carry supplies and paper weighing at least than 50 lbs 6. Perform a Lifeguard Skills test during the interview process; includes endurance, a timed event, and demonstration of CPR and lifeguard rescue skills 7. See and observe all sections of an assigned zone or area of responsibility
SENSORY ABILITY: 1. Visual Acuity 2. Auditory Acuity

Job.JobDescription:
The Varsity Assistant Boys Volleyball Coach role at Manheim Township High School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Varsity Assistant Boys Volleyball Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Manheim Township High School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Varsity Assistant Boys Volleyball Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Manheim Township High School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Varsity Assistant Boys Volleyball Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Varsity Assistant Boys Volleyball Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Varsity Assistant Boys Volleyball Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Manheim Township High School.

The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Southside High, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Varsity Football - Assistant Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Varsity Football - Assistant Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Southside High operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Southside High with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Varsity Football - Assistant Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Varsity Football - Assistant Coach role at Southside High.

The Adjunct Coach JV Wrestling position at J.L. Mann High provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Adjunct Coach JV Wrestling prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At J.L. Mann High, the Adjunct Coach JV Wrestling works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Adjunct Coach JV Wrestling encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Adjunct Coach JV Wrestling at J.L. Mann High is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: Adjunct Coach - Track & Field Jumpers Coach for SY 2025-2026
Job.JobDescription:
The Adjunct Coach - Track & Field Jumpers Coach for SY 2025 at Riverside High is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Adjunct Coach - Track & Field Jumpers Coach for SY 2025 is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Riverside High, the Adjunct Coach - Track & Field Jumpers Coach for SY 2025 helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Adjunct Coach - Track & Field Jumpers Coach for SY 2025 may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Riverside High well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Adjunct Coach - Track & Field Jumpers Coach for SY 2025 follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobDescription:

The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Hanahan High operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
