Job.JobDescription:
The Volleyball - Girls - 8th Grade Head Coach position at Worthingway Middle School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Volleyball - Girls - 8th Grade Head Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Worthingway Middle School, the Volleyball - Girls - 8th Grade Head Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Volleyball - Girls - 8th Grade Head Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Volleyball - Girls - 8th Grade Head Coach at Worthingway Middle School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobDescription:
The Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 at Lebanon Junior High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Lebanon Junior High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Lebanon City Schools: LJHS Cross Country Coach Assistant COED (Grades 7-8) Supplemental Position *2026 maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Lebanon Junior High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Lebanon City Schools: LHS Cross Country Coach Assistant ***2026-2027
Job.JobDescription:
The Lebanon City Schools: LHS Cross Country Coach Assistant *2026 at Lebanon High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Lebanon City Schools: LHS Cross Country Coach Assistant *2026 plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Lebanon High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Lebanon City Schools: LHS Cross Country Coach Assistant *2026 expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Lebanon City Schools: LHS Cross Country Coach Assistant *2026 supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Lebanon City Schools: LHS Cross Country Coach Assistant *2026 may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Lebanon High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

LEVEL B JONATHAN ALDER LOCAL SCHOOLS TITLE: Head Athletic Coach - supplemental position SUGGESTED QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Valid driver's license. 2. State of Ohio Teaching License (preferred, not required). 3. Coaching and administrative abilities. 4. Experience in related field 5. Required to maintain a valid Pupil Activity Permit Validation and all items required to obtain PAP via the Ohio Department of Education. Copies of all certifications must be on file prior to coaching. REPORTS TO: Athletic Director, Principal or Designee SALARY: Supplemental as per negotiated agreement POSITION GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self discipline, self confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc. SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal. 1.0 PROFESSIONAL & PERSONAL RELATIONSHIPS 1.02 Follows policy in the Athletic Handbook and meets all criteria as outlined in the job description. 1.03 Provides training rules to team members in writing and follows due process procedures. 1.04 Develops rapport with the athletic coaching staff. 1.05 Participates in in-service meetings and other activities to improve coaching performance. Attends meetings necessary to the welfare of the Athletic Department. 1.06 Develops sound public relations. Co-operates with newspapers, radio, T.V., Booster Club, and interested spectators. Upholds the integrity of the athletic program by refraining from making negative remarks. 1.07 Maintains suitable sideline conduct at games. Expects sportsmanlike behavior to be displayed by assistant coaches and athletes toward all individuals involved with the contest (officials, workers, fans, etc.). 1.08 Serves as a role model to players, coaches and spectators in demonstrating good sportsmanship and ethical behavior at all times. 1.09 Demonstrates respect for opponents before, during and after the contest. Displays modesty in victory and graciousness in defeat. 1.10 Works cooperatively with junior high coaches in developing a coordinated program. 1.11 Works cooperatively with Athletic Director and completes duties assigned to them 1.12 Attends all meetings called by the Athletic Director. 2. COACHING PERFORMANCE 2.01 Develops respect by example in appearance, manners, behavior, language, and sportsmanlike conduct during a contest. 2.02 Is well-versed and knowledgeable in matters pertaining to the sport. 2.03 Has individual and team discipline and control. 2.04 Is fair, understanding, tolerant, sympathetic and patient with team members. 2.05 Educates players on rules and regulations of the game. Expects players to follow them and to accept the decisions about the game made my officials. 2.06 Teaches sportsmanship and rewards players who are good sports. 2.07 Teaching ability is innovative using new coaching techniques and ideas in addition to sound, already proven methods of coaching. 2.08 Is prompt in meeting team for practices and games. 2.09 Shows an interest in athletes in off-season activities and classroom efforts. 2.10 Delegates authority with responsibility while remaining accountable for such delegations. 2.11 Team performance consistent with quality of athletes available. 2.12 Supervision of players in the locker room, practice, field, bus and other areas. 3. RELATED COACHING RESPONSIBILITIES 3.01 Is concerned about the care of equipment, including issue, collection, inventory and storage. 3.02 Is cooperative in preparation of non-league scheduling. 3.03 Is cooperative in helping service clubs, Booster Club, Recreation Department and other organizations in their projects, which in turn relate to our athletic program. 3.04 Follows proper procedure for purchase of equipment. 3.05 Operates sport within the budget as submitted.

The Head Softball Coach at Trey Jones is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Head Softball Coach manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Trey Jones, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Head Softball Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Head Softball Coach follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Head Softball Coach at Trey Jones allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Reports to: Athletic Director and Head Coach General Description: The position of assistant coach will be filled based upon input from the head coach, Athletic Director, and Building Principal and recommendation of the Superintendent to the Board of Education. The assistant coach must meet all provisions of the Lake Board of Education and the OHSAA.
Responsible to Athletic Director and head coach. Attend all meetings scheduled by the head coach. Assist in the administration of the athletic program. Demonstrate loyalty to the head coach and to the program. Maintain good public relations with those groups and individuals involved with the program. Support the Lake Athletic Booster Club. Conduct oneself in a professional manner at all times. Teach the values of good sportsmanship. Be available for Athletic Department meetings as necessary. Works through proper channels and protocol in referring parents or the public to appropriate administrative responses. Assume responsibilities of head coach in matters of supervision in absence of head coach.
Pre-Season responsibilities:
be in attendance from the first day of practice. assist with the supervision of practices and games. assist with the issuance of equipment. assist in pre-season conditioning as assigned by the head coach.
In-Season responsibilities:
carry out the duties assigned by the head coach. assist the trainer with his/her duties. scout other schools' teams as necessary. observe and communicate with feeder coaches in the program.
Off-season responsibilities:
assist in the collection, storage, and inventory of equipment. assist with banquet activities. attend clinics when possible. assist with the off-season conditioning program.
Qualifications:
Must possess a valid Pupil Activity Permit (and all necessary certificates).
Acts that are deemed as lude, sexual, or inappropriate will be viewed as unacceptable and may be considered as grounds for administrative action, dismissal, or termination of contract.

Supervise the physical examinations for each athlete.
EMPLOYMENT TYPE: PART-TIME, TEMPORARY OPENINGS: 1

The DANCE SPONSOR role at MacArthur Middle School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the DANCE SPONSOR is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at MacArthur Middle School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The DANCE SPONSOR listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the DANCE SPONSOR encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The DANCE SPONSOR follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At MacArthur Middle School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the DANCE SPONSOR at MacArthur Middle School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.
Job.Sport: Football, Basketball, Track & Field, Dance Team/Cheer

Job.JobDescription:
The DANCE SPONSOR at Central Middle School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the DANCE SPONSOR is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Central Middle School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The DANCE SPONSOR helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The DANCE SPONSOR works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Central Middle School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Central Middle School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the DANCE SPONSOR reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the DANCE SPONSOR role at Central Middle School.
Job.Sport: Football, Basketball, Track & Field, Dance Team/Cheer

Job.JobTitle: Head Girls Soccer Coach - Franklin HS - 26/27 SY - District Athletics
Job.JobDescription:
Posting Timeline This job is open until filled. Applications will be reviewed as received. Portland Public Schools reserves the right to make a hiring decision at any point during the posting period.
Position Details DISTRICT MISSION: At PPS, our goal is that by the end of elementary, middle and high school every student by name is meeting or exceeding academic standards and is fully prepared to make productive life decisions. DISTRICT PROFILE: To obtain more information about our district, schools, learning environment and programs, please go to https://www.pps.net/Domain/265.
Key points of the job description for a Varsity Head Coach: High ethical and professional standards. Direct a successful grade 9-12 program and oversee all facets of an entire community youth program. 3 years of High School coaching experience Be a role model for high school student-athletes. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports by encouraging student-athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program. Lead student-athletes in the support of other Portland Public Schools athletics and activities.
The Head Coach will be responsible for the following: Manage all aspects of the high school program including training, practice schedules and routines. Hire and oversee a staff of assistant coaches Provide regular communication with parents/families Regularly track the academic progress of all student athletes in the program and facilitate necessary supports to ensure their academic eligibility. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports and encourage athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program for athletics.
All new hired coaches will need to complete the following prior to employment: NFHS/ASEP Certification First Aid Card (CPR and AED trained) District Fingerprinting/Criminal check Completion of OSAA Concussion Test Completion of ODE Steroid Test Completion of OSAA Heat Test *Head Up Football *Cheer and Dance/Drill Spirit Safety Training Completion of Portland Public School District paperwork and trainings.
Applicant will be asked to apply online at our website and include the following: A cover letter detailing your experience. A current resume. A minimum of three letters of recommendation/reference.
All PPS job offers are contingent on the satisfactory completion of a background check, including fingerprinting and criminal records.
Salary Range - $6100.00 to $10,000.00
* There is no compensation for summer and out of season workouts.
Portland Public Schools (PPS) is seeking talented people from diverse backgrounds and experiences to lead change and inspire PPS students. At PPS, every employee, despite having different roles, is an educator. We hope to attract talented educators who model the core PPS Educator Essentials. With the District’s focus on eliminating systemic racism and its adverse impact on student learning, we seek to hire individuals who bring to our district a deep commitment to racial equity and social justice.
The District is committed to equal opportunity and nondiscrimination in all its educational and employment activities. The District prohibits discrimination based on perceived or actual race; national or ethnic origin; color; sex; religion; age; sexual orientation; gender expression or identity; pregnancy; marital status; veteran’s status; familial status; economic status or source of income; mental or physical disability or perceived disability; or military service.

Job.Experience: 3 years

Job.JobTitle: Track - Assistant Coach - McLoughlin Middle School
Job.JobDescription:
JOB TITLE: Assistant Athletic Coach - Middle School CLASSIFICATION: Extra Duty SUPERVISOR: Building Principal CONTRACT: Athletic Season
GENERAL STATEMENT OF RESPONSIBILITIES The Assistant Coach will work to carry out the aims and objectives of the sport program as outlined by the Head Coach. The Assistant Coach is to instruct athletes in individual and team fundamentals, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success.
It is the intent of this job description to give sufficient guidance to function. In case not specifically covered, it shall be assumed that a coach shall exercise common sense and good judgment.
The Assistant Coach supervises athletes and teams assigned to him/her and assumes supervising control over all athletes in program when such control is needed.
DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES 1. Has a thorough knowledge of all the Athletic Policies endorsed by the Medford School District Board of Education and is responsible for its compliance. 2. Has knowledge of Southern Oregon Junior High Athletic Conference rules and regulations implements those same consistently and is responsible for compliance. 3. Understands the proper administrative line of command and refers all requests or grievances through proper channels. 4. Works to increase morale and cooperation within the school's entire athletic program. 5. Knows effective safety procedures in their sport, plans and implements a program of instruction in safe practices.
ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES 1. Assists the Head Coach in scheduling and making travel arrangements when asked. 2. Works with the Head Coach to prepare and adhere to scheduled facility times. 3. Provides documentation to fulfill state and district requirements concerning physical examinations, parent consent, and eligibility. 4. Provides proper safeguards for maintenance and protection of assigned equipment and facilities. 5. Is accountable for all equipment. 6. Advises the Head Coach and recommends policy, method or procedural changes. 7. Assists in the necessary preparation to hold scheduled sport events or practices and adheres to scheduled facility times. 8. Assists in cleaning, repairing, and storing of all athletic equipment. 9. Performs other such duties that are consistent with the nature of the position and that may be requested by the Head Coach.
STUDENT RESPONSIBILITIES 1. Serves as a role model for students. 2. Emphasizes good sportsmanship and desirable pupil/teacher relationships. 3. Develops and organizes practice schedule to provide both individual and team development. 4. Organizes and supervises practice sessions. 5. Teaches individual fundamental skills, team plan, team strategy, and rules and regulations of the sport. 6. Respects the integrity and personality of the individual athlete. 7. Abides by the rules and regulations of the building, the District, and the OSAA.
EQUIPMENT AND FACILITIES 1. Is accountable to the Head Coach for all equipment. 2. Is knowledgeable of the care and maintenance of equipment. 3. Recommends to the Head Coach budgetary items for the next year in his/her area of the program. 4. Assists the Head Coach with issuing and collecting equipment and maintaining a correct inventory. 5. Monitors the security of the facilities and equipment. 6. Instructs athletes in the proper care of equipment.
QUALIFICATIONS: To perform this position successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skill, and/or ability required. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
MINIMUM SKILLS AND ABILITIES: Knowledge: 1. Of rules and regulations of the sport to which assigned. 2. Of fundamentals, techniques, and strategies of the sport to which assigned. 3. Of safety factors involved in the sport assigned. 4. Of physical ability and limitations of the level he/she is teaching. 5. Of the Medford School District Athletic Policies and OSAA Rules and Regulations. Skills: 1. Must possess the ability to communicate effectively with people. 2. Must be able to demonstrate basic skills of sport to which assigned. 3. Must have the ability to organize, supervise, and evaluate the total sport program. Attitudes: 1. Must be positive. 2. Should be enthusiastic. 3. Should possess a willingness to cooperate and to adjust to various situations. Experience: 1. Previous coaching experience of sport to which assigned is preferred. 2. Previous experience as participant of sport to which assigned preferred. 3. Previous teaching experience preferred. Education: 1. Valid Oregon teacher certification is preferred. 2. College training in coaching desirable.
PHYSICAL DEMANDS AND WORKING CONDITIONS: The physical demands described below are representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform the essential functions of this position. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
Lifting Requirements: Light (20 pounds maximum) Medium (50 pounds maximum) Heavy (100 pounds maximum) Other Conditions: May have to lift more than 100 pounds. Environmental Conditions: Mainly indoors Both inside and outside Mainly outside
Job.Experience: Previous coaching experience of sport to which assigned is preferred.

Job.JobDescription:
Coach: Head Girls Soccer - West Linn High School
This position starts August 14, 2026. Pay rates are currently in progress of being updated per MOU.
Positive leader with effective communication skills in directing a quality high school soccer program. Effective teacher at the game, developing individual skills and competitive teams; qualified experience in directing a total quality program and guiding students-athletes; liaison with the community youth programs; ability to work with other staff members, coaches, and administration.
Community and District Information:
The West Linn-Wilsonville School District is nestled within two thriving cities, West Linn and Wilsonville, within the rural area of Clackamas County. Both communities have a strong legacy of support for their schools, music and arts endeavors, and the overall well-being of their patrons. The school district and surrounding communities have experienced steady, constant growth over the past three decades. The estimated student population of the District as of December 2024 is 8,900.
It is the policy of the West Linn-Wilsonville Board of Education and School District (WLWV) that no discrimination or harassment on the grounds of race, color, national origin, religion, sex, sexual orientation, age, marital status, veterans' status, genetic information, or disability shall occur if the employee with or without reasonable accommodation, is able to perform the essential functions of the position. These protections apply to students, employees, and other members of the public. West Linn-Wilsonville School District is committed to equal access and equal opportunity in all activities/services, educational programs, and employment. Persons having questions regarding equal opportunity and nondiscrimination should contact the Director of Human Resources at the West Linn-Wilsonville School District, 503-673-7018.
Job.Location: West Linn High School - West Linn, Oregon

Job.JobTitle: .5 FTE Assistant Track Coach - Caldera High School - Regular
Job.JobDescription:
Bend-La Pine Schools is committed to the principle of equity. Equity supersedes the notion of equality, where all are treated the same. Pursuing equity requires the removal of barriers and the promotion of inclusive practices so that all students fully benefit. The principle of equity will inform all BLS policies, regulations, programs, operations, practices, and resource allocations.
Our goal is to find the best candidate for the position, and we acknowledge that that candidate may be an individual from a less traditional background. We encourage you to apply, even if you don't believe you meet every one of our qualifications described. If you are unsure whether you meet the qualifications of a position, or how this would be determined, please feel free to contact Human Resources to discuss your application.
As you prepare to submit your application for employment, please note that all consideration of experience for the position and initial salary placements will be based upon the information you submit with your original application. Resumes must be detailed and verifiable for successful experience credit, any information provided to Bend-La Pine Schools at a later date will not be the basis for adjustments in salary placement.
Bend La Pine Schools Assistant Coaching Details
General Job Qualifications and Key Responsibilities of the Assistant Coach:
Hold high ethical and professional standards. Be an appropriate role model for high school student-athletes. Hold high expectations and accountability both behaviorally and academically for all student-athletes and coaching staff. Ability to develop, articulate, and implement a vision for your individual discipline. Ability to work in a cooperative and harmonious manner in an educationally based, school-wide athletic program. Experience in the specific discipline at high school level preferred. Be relationship/process oriented. Be involved in fundraising for the program. Communicate effectively with head coach and athletic director. Be an advocate for the multi-sport athlete. Be a supporter of the head coach and the direction they are taking the program. Other duties as assigned by Head Coach & Athletic Director.
Newly hired coaches will be required to complete or show proof of the following certifications prior to employment: 1. NFHS Fundamentals of Coaching (one-time requirement, previous completion will be recognized) 2. Concussion in Sports (yearly) 3. Heat Illness Prevention (every 4 years) District Background check 4. Appearance and Performance Enhancing Drugs and Substances Training (every 4 years) 5. Heads up certification (Yearly) (Football only)
Job.Location: Caldera High School, 60925 SE 15th Street, Bend, OR, 97702, United States

Job.JobTitle: Head Boys Golf Coach - Benson HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics
Job.JobDescription:
Posting Timeline This job is open until filled. Applications will be reviewed as received. Portland Public Schools reserves the right to make a hiring decision at any point during the posting period.
Position Details DISTRICT MISSION: At PPS, our goal is that by the end of elementary, middle and high school every student by name is meeting or exceeding academic standards and is fully prepared to make productive life decisions. DISTRICT PROFILE: To obtain more information about our district, schools, learning environment and programs, please go to https://www.pps.net/Domain/265. Key points of the job description for a Varsity Head Coach: High ethical and professional standards. Direct a successful grade 9-12 program and oversee all facets of an entire community youth program. 3 years of High School coaching experience Be a role model for high school student-athletes. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports by encouraging student-athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program. Lead student-athletes in the support of other Portland Public Schools athletics and activities.
The Head Coach will be responsible for the following: Manage all aspects of the high school program including training, practice schedules and routines. Hire and oversee a staff of assistant coaches Provide regular communication with parents/families Regularly track the academic progress of all student athletes in the program and facilitate necessary supports to ensure their academic eligibility. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports and encourage athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program for athletics.
All new hired coaches will need to complete the following prior to employment: NFHS/ASEP Certification First Aid Card (CPR and AED trained) District Fingerprinting/Criminal check Completion of OSAA Concussion Test Completion of ODE Steroid Test Completion of OSAA Heat Test *Head Up Football *Cheer and Dance/Drill Spirit Safety Training Completion of Portland Public School District paperwork and trainings.
Applicant will be asked to apply online at our website and include the following: A cover letter detailing your experience. A current resume. A minimum of three letters of recommendation/reference.
All PPS job offers are contingent on the satisfactory completion of a background check, including fingerprinting and criminal records.
Salary Range - $6100.00 to $10,000.00 * There is no compensation for summer and out of season workouts.
Portland Public Schools (PPS) is seeking talented people from diverse backgrounds and experiences to lead change and inspire PPS students. At PPS, every employee, despite having different roles, is an educator. We hope to attract talented educators who model the core PPS Educator Essentials. Job.JobTitle: 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract - MS - ASST. Coach - Girls Soccer FMS
Job.JobDescription:
The 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract - MS - ASST. Coach - Girls Soccer FMS at FUGETT MIDDLE SCHOOL is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract - MS - ASST. Coach - Girls Soccer FMS manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At FUGETT MIDDLE SCHOOL, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract - MS - ASST. Coach - Girls Soccer FMS demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract - MS - ASST. Coach - Girls Soccer FMS follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the 2026-2027 (Fall) Supplemental Contract - MS - ASST. Coach - Girls Soccer FMS at FUGETT MIDDLE SCHOOL allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobTitle: Anticipated Football Assistant Coach - Fall 2026 Season
Job.JobDescription:
The Anticipated Football Assistant Coach - Fall 2026 Season position at Red Land High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Anticipated Football Assistant Coach - Fall 2026 Season prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Red Land High School, the Anticipated Football Assistant Coach - Fall 2026 Season works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Anticipated Football Assistant Coach - Fall 2026 Season encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Anticipated Football Assistant Coach - Fall 2026 Season at Red Land High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.
Job.CompanyDescription: West Shore School District coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: Anticipated Field Hockey Head Coach - Fall 2026 Season
Job.JobDescription:
The Anticipated Field Hockey Head Coach - Fall 2026 Season position at Red Land High School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Anticipated Field Hockey Head Coach - Fall 2026 Season is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Red Land High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Anticipated Field Hockey Head Coach - Fall 2026 Season encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Anticipated Field Hockey Head Coach - Fall 2026 Season also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Anticipated Field Hockey Head Coach - Fall 2026 Season role at Red Land High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.
Job.JobType: Extra Duty Positions/Field Hockey Coaching Positions

Job.JobTitle: Anticipated Football Assistant Coach (.5) - Fall 2026 Season
Job.JobDescription:
The Anticipated Football Assistant Coach (.5) - Fall 2026 Season role at Red Land High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Anticipated Football Assistant Coach (.5) - Fall 2026 Season is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Red Land High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Anticipated Football Assistant Coach (.5) - Fall 2026 Season listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Anticipated Football Assistant Coach (.5) - Fall 2026 Season encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Anticipated Football Assistant Coach (.5) - Fall 2026 Season follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Red Land High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Anticipated Football Assistant Coach (.5) - Fall 2026 Season at Red Land High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
The 9th Grade Boys Football Coach at Plymouth Whitemarsh High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the 9th Grade Boys Football Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Plymouth Whitemarsh High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The 9th Grade Boys Football Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the 9th Grade Boys Football Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the 9th Grade Boys Football Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Plymouth Whitemarsh High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.
Job.Experience: Playing and/or coaching experience is preferred

Job.JobDescription:
The Head High School Softball Coach provides leadership, guidance, and instruction to build a successful and competitive softball program. This position is responsible for shaping the athletic and personal development of student-athletes by emphasizing skill improvement, teamwork, accountability, and sportsmanship. The coach plans and leads all practices, develops effective game strategies, and prepares players for regular-season and postseason competition, while fostering a positive and respectful team culture.
Job Summary: Promote, select, supervise and instruct student athletes in the sport. Coordinate, supervise, direct and help evaluate Assistant Coaches assigned to that sport.
Primary Duties and Responsibilities: Promote, select, supervise and instruct student-athletes on accordance with established District, Conference and PIAA standards and regulations. Team selection is subject to the Athletic Director’s review and approval. Know the rules of the game and instruct participants using current and appropriate coaching methods and strategies that promote good health and safety practices, physical fitness, sportsmanship, and skill development. Project a positive model for student-athletes, the general student body, and the community at large through appearance, positive attitude and enthusiastic personality, emotional maturity, self-control, leadership, planning, preparation and good sportsmanship. Maintain effective communications with students, parents, staff, administration, the media and higher institutions of higher education. Explain the expectations of the head coach to each assistant coach as it pertains to performance and the evaluation of performance. Conduct and attend meetings as mandated by the PIAA, the Conference, and as assigned by the Athletic Director or assigned principal. Plan and schedule, in coordination with the Athletic Director, all practices and recommend use of facilities. Maintain accurate and timely records as mandated by the PIAA, the Conference, and as directed by the Athletic Director. Acquire and maintain First Aid and CPR certification yearly (provided by Central York School District), and administer emergency treatment of injuries in the absence of a trainer, physician, or other person more qualified than him/herself. Safeguard all equipment and facilities to assure safety and proper use. Maintain an up-to-date and accurate inventory of all equipment and supplies used in the sport. Annually prepare and submit a detailed requisition for equipment and supplies needed for the following year to the Athletic Director. Promote positive self-esteem and climate among all participants and provide for appropriate recognition of student-athlete achievement in accordance with District, Conference and PIAA standards and practices. Promote appropriate use of language. Complete additional duties as assigned by the Athletic Director or assigned principal.
Where: Central York High School 601 Mundis Mill Road York, PA 17406
Qualifications: Must demonstrate the ability to be organized and have good communication skills Must have ( or willing to obtain) current PA Criminal, PA Child Abuse and FBI Criminal History Background Checks
Job.Location: Central York High School, 601 Mundis Mill Road, York, PA 17406

Job.JobDescription:
The Boys Volleyball - Assistant Coach position at William Tennent High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Boys Volleyball - Assistant Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At William Tennent High School, the Boys Volleyball - Assistant Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Boys Volleyball - Assistant Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Boys Volleyball - Assistant Coach at William Tennent High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.
Job.Experience: Must possess significant and successful coaching experience

Job.JobTitle: Outdoor Track - Assistant Coaches (Boys and Girls)
Job.JobDescription:
The Outdoor Track - Assistant Coaches (Boys and Girls) position at William Tennent High School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Outdoor Track - Assistant Coaches (Boys and Girls) is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At William Tennent High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Outdoor Track - Assistant Coaches (Boys and Girls) encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Outdoor Track - Assistant Coaches (Boys and Girls) also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Outdoor Track - Assistant Coaches (Boys and Girls) role at William Tennent High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.
Job.Experience: Must possess significant and successful coaching experience

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Middle School Girls Volleyball Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Middle School Girls Volleyball Coach at Carlisle Area is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Assistant Middle School Girls Volleyball Coach manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Carlisle Area, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Assistant Middle School Girls Volleyball Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Assistant Middle School Girls Volleyball Coach follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Assistant Middle School Girls Volleyball Coach at Carlisle Area allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobTitle: Boys' Wrestling - Head Middle School Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Boys' Wrestling - Head Middle School Coach at Cedar Crest Middle School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Boys' Wrestling - Head Middle School Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Cedar Crest Middle School, the Boys' Wrestling - Head Middle School Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Boys' Wrestling - Head Middle School Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Cedar Crest Middle School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Boys' Wrestling - Head Middle School Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.
Job.Location: Cedar Crest Middle School 101 East Evergreen Road Lebanon, PA 17042

Job.JobDescription:
Position Title: Varsity Assistant Girls' Volleyball Coach
Job Goal: This position involves coaching, mentoring, and guiding student-athletes in individual skill development and team strategies. The coach will also be responsible for fostering a positive and inclusive team culture, ensuring the safety and well-being of players, and always representing the school professionally.
Qualifications: Minimum of 3 years coaching experience (head coaching preferred) Proven coaching techniques and in-depth knowledge, including rules, strategies, and district and PIAA regulations Strong communication, organizational, and leadership skills Ability to foster effective relationships with administrators, staff, students, parents, and governing bodies Commitment to academic and personal development of student-athletes Ability to assess and develop players and coaches Professional demeanor and motivational leadership Effective communicator with strong human relations skills Commitment to equity, diversity, and inclusion Willingness to uphold school policies and work flexible hours, including evenings and weekends Availability to meet with students and parents outside of instructional hours A head coach/assistant coach must be dedicated to organizing and maintaining a structured off-season workout program that supports the ongoing development of their athletes. This involves planning and supervising conditioning, skill-building, and strength training sessions to ensure progress throughout the year and team readiness.

Questions may be directed to the Athletics Department at 717-270-6770 or asinico@lebanon.k12.pa.us All required clearances must comply with the Pennsylvania Department of Education's mandated criteria for hire.
Application Deadline: The position will remain open until the appropriate candidate is selected.

Job.JobDescription:
The Girls Track Head Coach role at Quakertown High School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Girls Track Head Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Quakertown High School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Girls Track Head Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Quakertown High School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Girls Track Head Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Girls Track Head Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Girls Track Head Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Quakertown High School.

Job.JobTitle: Copy Of Flag Football - Girls Varsity Assistant Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Copy Of Flag Football - Girls Varsity Assistant Coach at North Hills School District is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Copy Of Flag Football - Girls Varsity Assistant Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at North Hills School District use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Copy Of Flag Football - Girls Varsity Assistant Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Copy Of Flag Football - Girls Varsity Assistant Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Copy Of Flag Football - Girls Varsity Assistant Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at North Hills School District. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

The PWHS Baseball Boys Assistant Coach position at Penn Wood High School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the PWHS Baseball Boys Assistant Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The PWHS Baseball Boys Assistant Coach at Penn Wood High School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Penn Wood High School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The PWHS Baseball Boys Assistant Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The PWHS Baseball Boys Assistant Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the PWHS Baseball Boys Assistant Coach position at Penn Wood High School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.
